questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a purulent skin abscess on his forearm. He complains of pain, redness, and swelling at the site of the lesion. You suspect a Staphylococcus aureus infection. What selective media can be used to culture Staphylococcus aureus from the clinical specimen?
questions.solution:
Ludlam's medium is a selective culture medium used to isolate staphylococcus aureus. 

Ludlam's medium consists of lithium chloride and tellurite, and helps in the isolation of Staphylococci when they are expected to be scanty or outnumbered by other bacteria.

Other selective media used for Staphylococci include salt-milk agar, salt broth, polymyxin, Roberts' cooked meat medium containing 10% sodium chloride.

Other options: 

Option A:  MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium primarily used for the isolation and differentiation of enteric gram-negative bacteria based on lactose fermentation.

Option B: Thayer-Martin agar is a selective medium used for the isolation of Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis.

Option D: Pike's medium is used as a transport medium for Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady was found to have multiple hamartomatous GI polyps. Her family history is significant for breast and thyroid cancer in his mother. On examination, the following lesions were identified. Which of the following disorders is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Cowden's syndrome. The given clinical scenario of multiple hamartomatous GI polyps with a family history of breast cancer and thyroid cancer; and the presence of facial trichilemmomas and cobblestone appearance of multiple papillomatous papules in the oral mucosa is suggestive of Cowden's syndrome.

Cowden’s syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by familial germline loss of function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene, PTEN on chromosome 10 resulting in increased PI3K/AKT pathway signalling. It predisposes to various epithelial tumours.

Epithelial tumours associated with Cowden’s syndrome are multiple hamartomatous GI polyps, breast cancer, endometrial cancer and thyroid cancer. Mucocutaneous manifestations of the syndrome include facial trichilemmomas which is a benign appendageal tumor, oral mucosal papillomatosis showing cobblestone appearance, acral keratosis and palmoplantar keratosis.

Other options -

Option A - Lynch syndrome is the most common inherited cause of colonic cancer (right colon). Inherited mutations of genes MSH2 or MLH1 leading to defective DNA mismatch repair results in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer(Lynch syndrome). It is mainly associated with early onset endometrial cancer, urothelial cancers of renal pelvis and cutaneous manifestations such as sebaceous adenomas.

Option C - Familial adenomatous polyposis(FAP) syndrome is caused due to a germline loss of function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene, APC(adenomatous polyposis coli) on the 5th chromosome leading to multiple adenomas in the GI tract with 100% risk of malignant conversion associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium hypertrophy. Variants of FAP are Gardner and Turcot syndromes.

Option D - Tuberous sclerosis is also associated with multiple hamartomatous GI polyps but the absence of the classical triad (epiloia) of epilepsy, low intelligence and adenoma sebaceum rules out as possible diagnosis. Other associated features are facial angiofibromas, cortical(CNS) tubers and renal angiomyolipoma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with progressive distension of the abdomen. On examination, she was found to have ascites. Investigation revealed a right-sided pleural effusion and an ovarian mass. A provisional diagnosis of Meigs syndrome was made. The ovarian tumor is likely to be:
questions.solution:
The most likely type of ovarian tumor in Meigs syndrome is fibroma.  

Meigs syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  • Ovarian fibroma
  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion

It can also be seen with the granulosa cell tumor and Brenner's tumor. The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though left-sided and bilateral effusions are possible. Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after removing the tumor. 

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign ovarian tumors such as teratoma, struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, etc.

Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome can present as a manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with progressive conductive hearing loss was found to have otosclerotic foci on the entire footplate along with complete involvement of the oval window. What type of otosclerosis is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
The otosclerotic foci found on the entire footplate of stapes along with complete involvement of the oval window is an obliterative type of stapedial otosclerosis.

The stapedial type of otosclerosis presents predominantly with a bilateral conductive type of deafness and can be of various types:

  • Anterior focus: Involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
  • Posterior focus: Only fissula post fenestrum
  • Circumferential: Around the margin of the stapes footplate
  • Biscuit type: Entire footplate except for the annular ligament
  • Obliterative: Entire footplate when it completely obliterates the oval window niche.

Otosclerosis is a bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. This condition worsens during stress and conditions with hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis Any site but asymptomatic

 

Clinical features

  • An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.
  • In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The image below shows the Schwartze sign.

  • Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).
  • Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch. 

The image below shows Carhart's notch in pure tone audiometry. 

  • Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicating that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. 

The image below shows As type of curve in tympanometry which is seen in otosclerosis.

  • As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Image below shows stapedotomy procedure.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. On microscopic examination, plenty of pus cells were found and culture on MacConkey agar showed colorless colonies. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella.

Enrichment media is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow.

Shigellae are short, gram-negative rods that are non-motile, non-sporing, and non-capsulated. They are indole positive, urea and oxidase negative, and ferment glucose. Colonies on MacConkey agar are colorless due to the absence of lactose fermentation. Hektoen enteric (HE) agar, xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar (XLD), and deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) are the highly selective mediums used for subculture. Growth is inhibited on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium.

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

Other options:

Option A: Robertson's cooked meat broth is used for the culture of anaerobic organisms. 

Option B: Alkaline peptone water is used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea. It is an enrichment media.

Option D: Brain-heart infusion broth is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

questions.text:
A woman presented to an obstetrician with a history of missed period. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks back. Her UPT was positive. A transvaginal ultrasound was performed and the gestational sac was visualized. The frequency of the ultrasound probe used in this scenario is :

UPT- Urine pregnancy test
questions.solution:
The frequency of trans vaginal transducer is 5-10 MegaHertz.

Frequencies used in various other types of transducers:

  • Abdominal Transducer uses a frequency of 4-6 MegaHertz  (lower frequency penetrates better).
  • Vagina transducer uses a frequency of 5-10 MegaHertz (higher frequency yield better image with minimal penetration).
  • In the third trimester, a lower frequency i.e. 2-5 MHz transducer is needed for tissue penetration-particularly in obese patients.

Note :

Ultrasound refers to sound waves traveling at a frequency above 20,000 hertz.

questions.text: A factory worker met with a workplace accident that resulted in the amputation of his right thumb and index finger. Due to this, he became unable to write or eat with his right arm. He was compensated for the injury but was deemed unfit to continue working in the factory. Which of the following according to WHO is defined as ‘disability’?

choices.text: Loss of thumb and index finger

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, disability refers to his inability to write or eat. 

According to WHO, disability is defined as - any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being such as performing daily household tasks like eating and writing in this case.

The sequence of events leading to disability is -

                      Disease -> Impairment -> Disability -> Handicap

In the given scenario, the causative factor is a workplace accident. Impairment is amputation/loss of right thumb and index finger. Disability is his inability to perform normal day-to-day activities like eating and writing. Handicap is his inability to perform his social responsibilities of going to work.

The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, or anatomical structure or function". 

The WHO definition of a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfillment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability make them handicapped.

questions.text: Which of the following services are provided under the program represented by the logo below?

choices.text: Quality antenatal care free of cost on 9th of every month
Free transport service between home and institution
Improve quality of care in labor room and maternal OTs
Safe motherhood services including IFA tablets, Td vaccination

questions.solution:
The logo represents Laqshya. It is an initiative launched by the government of India to improve the quality of care in the labor room and maternal OTs. 

Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care that is provided to the pregnant mother in the labor room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges (MCs) besides district hospitals (DHs), high delivery load sub-district hospitals (SDHs), and community health centers (CHCs).

The initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labor rooms and also incentivize facilities to achieve the targets outlined. The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and newborn mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labor room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care. The complete logo of the program is shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Quality antenatal care (including investigations and drugs) is provided free of cost on the 9th of every month under Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA).

Option B: Free transport service from home to institution, between facilities in case of referral, and back to home is provided free of cost under the Janani-Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK). The main aim of JSSK is to provide no-expense delivery, including a cesarean section, to all pregnant women delivering in public health services.

Option C: Safe motherhood services including IFA tablets, Td vaccination are provided under the Vandematharam scheme which is a voluntary scheme.  It can be volunteered by an OBG specialist, lady doctor/ MBBS doctor, maternity home, or nursing home. The enrolled doctors are instructed to display the 'Vandemataram logo' at their clinic. The respective DMO will provide IFA tablets, OC pills, and Td injections to the Vandematharam doctors/ clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries.

questions.text: A child presents for a well-child visit. You observe that he is sitting in a tripod position. He has stranger anxiety on seeing you and babbles in monosyllables. The fine motor milestones likely to be attained by the child at this age are:

choices.text: Tower of two blocks, imitates scribbling

questions.solution:
Sitting in a tripod fashion, recognizing strangers and having stranger anxiety, and speaking in monosyllables indicate that the child is most likely to be six months old. The fine motor milestones likely to be attained at this age are unidextrous reach and being able to transfer objects.

The developmental milestones at the age of six months are:

  • Fine motor and adaptive: reaches out for objects with one hand - unidextrous reach and transfers objects from one hand to another
  • Gross motor: Independently sits with arms forward for support - "tripod" fashion
  • Social and adaptive milestones: Recognises strangers, stranger anxiety
  • Language milestones: Monosyllables like ba, da, pa

Other options:

Option B: A child attains a mature pincer grasp only around 12 months of age. 

Option C: A child can build a tower of two blocks and imitate scribbling around 15 months of age.

Option D: A child can build a tower of three blocks and scribble around 18 months of age.

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. A few days later, she presented with deep vein thrombosis. Her platelet count was found to be 60,000/microliter. Which of the following anticoagulants should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Warfarin can decrease protein C levels and may precipitate venous limb gangrene or skin necrosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Therefore, it should not be used until the platelet count returns to normal.

HIT is caused due to the development of IgG antibodies against complexes of heparin with platelet factor 4 (or other chemokines).

HIT usually starts 5-10 days after starting heparin. The patients will have platelet count <1,50,000/mL or reduced by 50% or more from the pre-treatment value. These are more common with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMWH) and also more common in women.

Venous thrombosis (in the form of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) is more common than arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis can cause limb ischemia, myocardial infarction, or stroke. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage and skin lesions at the site of subcutaneous heparin injection can also be seen.

The diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia can be confirmed by enzyme-linked immunoassays to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes, platelet activation assays, and serotonin release assay.

Management of HIT includes:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH.
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. LMWH should be avoided because it cross-reacts with heparin antibodies.
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with multiple injuries following a road traffic accident within 2 hours. The patient was bleeding actively for which damage control resuscitation measures were done. Which of the following measures is not part of damage control resuscitation?
questions.solution:
2:1 FFP-RBC transfusion is not part of damage control resuscitation(DCR). Instead a balanced transfusion of FFP and RBC in the ratio of 1:1. If platelets are also indicated, they are also given in equal ratio to that of other blood products. (Option D)

Damage control resuscitation(DCR) is a trauma approach model in patients that prioritises haemorrhage control in a patient who is actively bleeding internally or externally. The rationale is that hemorrhagic shock due to ongoing bleeding resulting in poor end­-organ perfusion, hypothermia and lactic acidosis cannot be corrected while patients are actively bleeding. 

The conventional approach of repeated cycles of high-volume resuscitation in the form of intravenous fluids will only cause dilutional coagulopathy, hypothermia and metabolic derangements such as acidosis, hyperkalaemia and hypocalcaemia. The introduction of DCR has been associated with substantial reductions in mortality from haemorrhagic shock.


DCR is based on four key principles – 

Rapid haemorrhage control in the form of direct pressure over the site of external haemorrhage, temporary bleeding control with the help of tourniquets, balloon occlusion or other techniques. Internal haemorrhage is treated with the help of damage control surgery in which the surgical approach is to stop bleeding, control of sepsis, prevent further injury and not definitive repair of damaged structures. Sometimes interventional radiology may be required. (Option B)

Permissive hypotension mainly to reduce blood loss from bleeding sites. However, it is important to maintain baseline perfusion of the coronary arteries through a mean arterial pressure above 50 mm Hg by whatever means available. (Option A)

Avoid dilutional coagulopathy by avoiding clear fluids (crystalloids or colloids) and by giving a transfusion that approximates whole blood – usually administered as equal volumes of packed red blood cells and plasma.

Treat existing coagulation deficits empirically or by regular coagulation testing and acting on the results. Tranexamic acid should be given as soon as possible in almost all bleeding patients to stop hyperfibrinolysis. Blood component concentrates such as cryoprecipitate for low fibrinogen levels or platelet transfusions for platelet dysfunctions. (Option C)

Following damage control resuscitation and achievement of hemostasis, resuscitation is now shifted towards end-organ perfusion in the form of warmed IV fluids, vasopressors and thromboprophylaxis if needed.

questions.text: A pathology student describes a microbial defence mechanism where neutrophils lose their nuclei. Which specific process is being referred to by the student?
questions.solution:
Neutrophils undergo cell death and lose their nuclei during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps.

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs): Extracellular fibrillar networks that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at sites of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

  • Viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin that concentrates antimicrobial peptides and enzymes.
  • In the process of NET formation, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost, leading to cell death.
  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly SLE.

The following image represents the process of microbial killing using the neutrophil extracellular trap. A neutrophil granulocyte (yellow) has ejected a NET (green) to capture bacteria (purple). A red blood cell (orange) is also trapped in the NET.


Other options: Various steps in leukocyte recruitment during inflammatory response:

Option A-Diapedesis - It is the migration of leukocytes through the endothelium towards the site of injury or infection, stimulated by the chemokines.

Option B-Margination- The process of leukocyte redistribution where more white cells assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface.

Option D-Oxidative burst- Microbes are killed after phagocytosis by producing reactive oxygen species (ROS). NADPH oxidase oxidises NADPH and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion (O2 • ). In neutrophils, this oxidative reaction is called the respiratory/oxidative burst.

questions.text: A postoperative patient on a ventilator was shifted to the intensive care unit for monitoring. When he woke up, he was unaware of his location, date, and time. He started to move violently on the bed and threw medicines at the nurses. Which of the following drugs having selective α2 agonist property can be used to sedate the patient?
questions.solution:
Dexmedetomidine can be used to sedate this patient.

Dexmedetomidine is a directly acting α2 -selective sympathomimetic drug. Activation of the α2A adrenergic receptor by dexmedetomidine produces both sedation and analgesia.

It is usually used in short-term sedation (<24 hours) of intubated patients and aids in easy awakening from the postoperative state without any respiratory depression. It is administered as an IV infusion. Side effects are hypotension, bradycardia, and dry mouth. 

Sympathomimetics are drugs that mimic the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. These are classified as:

  • Direct-acting (adrenergic receptor agonists) -  
    • Non-selective - epinephrine (α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3), noradrenaline (α1, α2, and β1), droxidopa (α and β)
    • Selective - 
      • α1-agonists such as phenylephrine and midodrine
      • α2-agonists such as apraclonidine, brimonidine, clonidine, guanabenz, α-methyl dopa, lofexidine, and tizanidine
      • β2-agonist such as terbutaline 
  • Indirect-acting (release epinephrine or noradrenaline to stimulate adrenergic receptors) - amphetamine, tyramine, etc
  • Mixed-acting - ephedrine

The various uses of α-agonists are:

  • Glaucoma - apraclonidine and brimonidine. They cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates, therefore contraindicated in children <2 years of age
  • Postural hypotension - prodrugs like midodrine and droxidopa 
  • Hypertension - centrally acting anti-hypertensives such as clonidine, guanabenz, and α-methyl dopa 
  • Opioid withdrawal - lofexidine
  • Muscle-relaxant - tizanidine

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the likely enzyme deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is caused by a deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme.

Type 1 tyrosinemia usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

An odor resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine are diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia): Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase deficiency
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Tyrosine transaminase deficiency
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia)

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase causes hyperammonemia type 2.

Option B: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase (also known as tyrosine aminotransferase) causes type 2 tyrosinemia.

Option C: Deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) causes hyperammonemia type 1. 

Note: A boiled cabbage odor can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: The post-mortem report of a young athlete who died of 'sudden cardiac death' indicates hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as the cause of death. Which of the following histopathological findings is most consistent with this disease?

choices.text: Myofibre disarray with exaggerated myocyte branching and interstitial fibrosis
Variable mycocyte hypertrophy, with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei
Loss of myocytes, with extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis
Interstitial lymphocytic infiltration, with focal myocyte necrosis

questions.solution:
Myofibre disarray with exaggerated myocyte branching and interstitial fibrosis.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a genetic disorder and is one of the most common causes of sudden, unexplained death in young athletes. In most cases, the pattern of transmission is autosomal dominant involving mutations in the sarcomeric proteins. Mutations causing HCM are found most commonly in the genes encoding myosin-binding protein C or β-myosin heavy chain, followed by the genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

The essential feature of HCM is massive myocardial hypertrophy and disproportionate thickening of the ventricular septum relative to the left ventricle free wall, termed asymmetric septal hypertrophy. 

The most important histologic features of HCM myocardium are

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy, with transverse myocyte diameters frequently greater than 40 μm (normal is approximately 15 μm) and exaggerated myocyte branching
  • Haphazard disarray of myocytes and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells (termed myofiber disarray)
  • Thickened intramural and septal vessels
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis 

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

HCM is characterized by reduced stroke volume due to impaired diastolic filling. Approximately 25% of patients with HCM have dynamic obstruction to the left ventricular outflow as the anterior mitral leaflet moves toward the ventricular septum during systole. The compromised cardiac output in conjunction with a secondary increase in pulmonary venous pressure explains the exertional dyspnea seen in these patients. 

Major clinical problems in HCM are atrial fibrillation, mural thrombus formation leading to embolization and stroke, cardiac failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and sudden death.

Most patients can be helped by pharmacologic intervention (e.g., β-adrenergic blockade) to decrease heart rate and contractility. Implantable cardioverter defibrillators are warranted for HCM patients at risk for ventricular arrhythmias. Some benefits can also be gained by the surgical excision of the septal muscle or by carefully controlled septal infarction through a catheter-based infusion of alcohol.

Other options :

Option B - Variable myocyte hypertrophy, with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei (Ninja star-like) is a feature of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Option C - Loss of myocytes, with extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis, is a finding observed in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

Option D - Interstitial lymphocytic infiltration, with focal myocyte necrosis is consistent with myocarditis.

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Missense mutation
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin
  • Myofibre disarray on histology
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:
    1. Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text: A pathologist utilizes the following symbol to represent a relationship in a pedigree chart. What does this depict?
questions.solution:
The symbol shown in the above image depicts a consanguineous marriage. 

Consanguineous marriages, also known as marriages between blood relatives, are categorized into different degrees based on the closeness of the relationship between the individuals involved. The degrees of consanguinity are typically classified as follows:

  1. First-degree consanguinity: This includes relationships between individuals who are closely related, such as siblings or parent-child relationships.
  2. Second-degree consanguinity: This category encompasses relationships between individuals who are slightly more distantly related, such as aunt/uncle-niece/nephew or grandparent-grandchild relationships.
  3. Third-degree consanguinity: These are relationships between individuals who are even more distantly related, such as first cousins.
  4. Fourth-degree consanguinity: This category includes relationships between individuals who are even more distantly related than first cousins, such as second cousins.

Certain diseases such as haemophilia, colour blindness, and diabetes are known to run through families. Schizophrenia, psychoneurosis and some forms of mental deficiency are also known to have a familial incidence. Thus the incidence of congenital malformation and the above diseases is higher among offsprings of consanguineous as compared with non-consanguineous marriages. 

Pedigree charts are graphical representations of a person's family tree and are useful for identifying the pattern of inheritance of genetic disorders. Thus, they are vital in the history-taking of patients, especially in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and enlarged lymph nodes. The microscopy of the patient's lymph node exudate shows the following appearance. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a man presenting with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and microscopy of the lymph node aspirate showing pilot wheel appearance is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis which is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioidomycosis, also known as South Americal blastomycosis, is a chronic granulomatous infection typically involving the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs.

The disease initially affects the lungs upon inhalation of the fungal spores and subsequently spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics where it can cause ulcers and granulomas. These are characteristic clinical findings.

The causative agent is a thermally dimorphic fungus. In infected tissues, it is seen in yeast form with large oval cells surrounded by multiple buds encircling the mother cell. This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance. The other form which exists is mycelium.

Microscopic examination of the sputum or other material from the lesions with potassium hydroxide (KOH) or calcofluor white stain helps demonstrate the presence of the fungus. Cultures on Sabouraud’s or yeast extract agar and serological examination are also helpful in the diagnosis.

Itraconazole is very effective against paracoccidioidomycosis, but ketoconazole and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can also be given. Severe disease is treated with amphotericin B.

The given image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis:

The given image shows swollen lymph nodes in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

The given image shows a CT scan of a patient with lung involvement in paracoccidioidomycosis. Note bilateral small nodules, ground-glass changes, and a cavitary lesion:

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic has been diagnosed with Korsakoffs psychosis. Which area of the brain is impacted during the chronic stages of his condition?
questions.solution:
In chronic cases of Korsakoff's psychosis, there will be atrophy of the mamillary bodies.

Periventricular lesions surrounding the third and the fourth ventricle are generally seen in acute cases of thiamine deficiency manifesting as Wernicke's encephalopathy. Wernicke's encephalopathy can lead to Korsakoff’s psychosis which is a chronic manifestation of thiamine deficiency. The amnestic episodes seen in Korsakoff's psychosis are associated with lesions in the dorsal medial nuclei of the thalamus.

The typical features of this disease is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory in an alert and responsive patient. Patients with Korsakoff's syndrome also typically have a change in personality, with a lack of initiative, reduced spontaneity, and a lack of interest. Confabulation is a characteristic feature of Korsakoff's psychosis which involves the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information.

questions.text: You are assisting your first case of open abdominal surgery. The senior professor asked you to make the incision first. The nurse hands over a fresh set of sterilized instruments with various Bard-Parker blades. Which blade would you choose generally for making an abdominal incision?
questions.solution:
The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin.

Other options-

Option (A): 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy. This is also known as a stab knife. 

Option (C): 15-blade for minor surgical procedures 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option (D): 12-blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman at 21 weeks gestation presents with  nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She complains of pain in the right lower quadrant which started a few hours back. There is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. USG showed an outer appendiceal diameter of 8mm with periappendiceal fluid collection. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Open appendicectomy, since Lap appendicectomy is contraindicated
Initiate Ochsner sherren regimen for management

questions.solution:
The clinical features and USG findings suggest the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Immediate open or laparoscopic appendicectomy is the next step in management.

Appendicitis is the most prevalent non-obstetric emergency during pregnancy. However, its clinical manifestation follows a typical pattern in only about 50% to 60% of cases. Early symptoms like nausea and vomiting, common in appendicitis, are nonspecific and can also occur in normal pregnancy.

Ultrasound (US) is the initial preferred diagnostic method. If the results from the US are inconclusive, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a safe alternative. On USG, outer appendiceal diameter of more than 6mm, peri-appendiceal fluid collection, and probe tenderness are suggestive of acute appendicitis.

Laparoscopic appendicectomy is currently the preferred surgical approach for pregnant patients although open appendicectomy can also be performed. However, there is no definitive conclusion from studies comparing the outcomes of open appendicectomy versus laparoscopic procedures. 

There is insufficient evidence to support non-operative/ conservative management of appendicitis during pregnancy like the Ochsner sherren regimen (Option D) and it is generally discouraged due to the increased risk of complications.

Interval appendicectomy (Option C) is performed after a waiting period of 6 weeks for the inflammation to settle in cases of appendicular lump where it is primarily managed by conservative treatment like Ochsner sherren regimen.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: What does the term folate trap refer to?
questions.solution:
The term folate trap refers to accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate with deficiency of tetrahydrofolate. It is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, vitamin B12 deficiency leads to folate deficiency.

Since vitamin B12 is also linked to regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, there is hyperhomocysteinemia as well. It increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension and thrombosis.

questions.text: Nayi Pahel kits are distributed to newly wedded couples under the family planning programme. Which of the following items is present in the kit?
questions.solution:
Urine pregnancy kits are present in the Nayi Pahel kits distributed to newly wedded couples for a subsidised fee of Rs 220 under the family planning programme - Mission Parivar Vikas. 

It is a family planning kit consisting of -

  • jute bag with family planning programme logo
  • Marriage registration form
  • A pamphlet containing information on contraception, family planning, how to use UPT kits   and ASHA schemes
  • Pack of 3 male condom(Nirodh) x 2 units
  • Mala N oral contraceptive pills x 2 packs
  • 3 emergency contraceptive pills called E pills
  • 2 pregnancy testing kits
  • A grooming or hygiene kit consisting mirror, lipstick, bindi, etc

The ASHA is incentivized 100/kit distributed to newly wedded couples.

questions.text: A child with a history of atopic dermatitis and close contact with his relatives presented with high fever, lymphadenopathy, and disseminated vesicles as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of atopic dermatitis with high fever, lymphadenopathy, and disseminated vesicular lesions on an erythematous base is suggestive of Kaposi varicelliform eruption.

Kaposi varicelliform eruption, also known as eczema herpeticum commonly occurs in patients with a history of atopic dermatitis and is triggered by viral infections, most commonly herpes simplex virus which may result in the spread of infection throughout the ecazematous areas. It typically presents as fever, lymphadenopathy, and vesicles that are widely disseminated on an erythematous base and may become hemorrhagic. The fever subsides in 4 to 5 days and the pustules heal with crusting, leaving some permanent scarring. The lesions may have a punched-out appearance and can be widespread, involving the face, trunk, and extremities.

Oral or intravenous acyclovir is used for the treatment depending on the severity of the infection.

Other options:

Option A: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with Celiac disease. It includes intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks.

Option C: Herpes Zoster or Shingles is a viral infection caused due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. It typically causes burning, painful vesicles that are usually confined to a single dermatome on one side of the body. 

Option D: Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules. It is caused by the pox virus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presented with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth. A pre-malignant oral lesion is suspected. What is the next best step in the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker presenting with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth is suggestive of erythroplakia and the next best step is to do an excision biopsy of the lesion.(Option B)

Erythroplakia is a pre-malignant oral lesion that presents as a bright red velvety patch or plaque commonly at the lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus and the floor of the mouth. The red colour is due to decreased keratinization and as a result, the red vascular connective tissue of the submucosa shines through. 

Grossly, the lesion may be of three varieties—homogenous, speckled or granular, and erythroplakia, interspersed with areas of leukoplakia. Malignant potential is 17 times higher than in leukoplakia, hence excision biopsy and follow-up are indicated in such cases.

Other options -

Option A) Topical steroids are used to treat oral submucous fibrosis which is another premalignant condition of the oral cavity strongly associated with areca nut and tobacco chewing.  

Option C) Radiotherapy is used as a primary modality in the treatment of Stage 2(T2N0M0) carcinoma of buccal mucosa and tongue. T2 refers to the size of tumor - 2 to 4cm. It is also used as an adjuvant therapy post-surgery in stages 3 and 4 of carcinoma of the oral cavity.

Option D) Laser ablation or cryotherapy can be done in small lesions of leukoplakia provided biopsy ruled out malignancy.

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected cells: Shows koilocytes. These cells have hyperchromatic enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halo.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes(right side) compared to normal Pap smear(left side).

questions.text: A diabetic patient develops severe diplopia while looking down on her sewing machine due to paresis of a muscle that is responsible for depression, intorsion and abduction of the eye. Identify the appropriate option regarding the origin of the nerve supplying this muscle.

choices.text: Dorsal midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus
Ventral midbrain at the level of superior colliculus
Dorsal Midbrain at the level of superior colliculus
Ventral midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus

questions.solution:
The above diabetic patient ( mononeuropathy )experiences diplopia in adduction ( sewing ). The muscle responsible for depression, intorsion, and abduction of the eye is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which originates from the dorsal aspect of the midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus. It is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem in the dorsal aspect.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve.
  • Only cranial nerve with dorsal exit. All other cranial nerves exit the brainstem from the ventral surface.
  • Emerges from the dorsal midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course.
  • Only nerve with internal decussation.

questions.text: A deltoid muscle biopsy of a Patient who works in a hamburger shop is given below. He is diagnosed with trichinosis. Choose the infective form of  the organism causing this condition
questions.solution:
The above clinical image of the deltoid muscle biopsy shows encysted spiral larvae, characteristic of Trichinella spiralis causing trichinosis in the patient. The infective form is the encysted larvae found in undercooked muscles of pigs and other animals.

Trichinella spiralis is a nematode known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhoea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

It is a self-limiting disease. The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

Spiral larvae are detected in muscle tissue by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied. Safranin staining is done.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

The following image shows the life cycle of Trichinella spiralis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presented with a firm, non-tender scrotal mass. He was previously treated surgically for undescended testes. Immunohistochemistry was positive for KIT, OCT 3/4, and podoplanin. AFP was negative, and serum androgens were normal. Ultrasound revealed a homogenous, hypoechoic intratesticular mass. What is the histopathological finding likely to be seen?

AFP - alpha feto protein

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
The clinical case and the history of cryptorchidism point to the diagnosis of seminoma. Histopathological finding seen in seminoma is a 'fried egg appearance' of cells.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor peaking in the fourth decade. It is the equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. A history of cryptorchidism increases the risk of developing seminoma.

Generally, it presents as a nodule or painless swelling of the testis. Sometimes, there might be the presence of a dull ache or heavy sensation in the lower abdomen, or scrotum. It can metastasize to many organs like the lymph nodes, lungs, brain, and gastrointestinal tract.

It is evaluated initially by laboratory tests and ultrasound scans. Serum tumor markers including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), are measured. Placental alkaline phosphatase can also be elevated. AFP is not elevated in pure seminomas. An ultrasound scan shows a homogeneous hypoechoic intratesticular mass. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin while it is negative for cytokeratin.

Grossly, the testis has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.

The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or watery cytoplasm with varying amounts of glycogen. A large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributes to the 'fried egg appearance'. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate. The below image shows the histological picture of a seminoma.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and resemble endodermal sinuses. They resemble glomerulus-like structures in the visceral and parietal layer while the central core consists of capillaries. It is commonly seen in children and infants up to 3 years of age. AFP is positive. The image of Schiller Duval bodies is shown below. 

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells. They are commonly seen in children or adults. Features include testicular swelling and gynecomastia. Serum androgens and estrogens are elevated. The image of Reinke crystals is shown below.

Option D: Teratoma can be seen in infants and children after yolk sac tumors. It consists of derivatives of all three germ layers. It includes islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, etc. Ultrasonography will show a heterogeneous mass with echogenic foci due to the presence of calcification, sebum, and hair.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl complains of intense scalp itching following a recent change of school. Examination findings are as shown. What treatment option is approved for this condition?

choices.text: Permethrin 1% lotion application, repeated after 7 days
Permethrin 5% lotion application, repeated after 7 days

questions.solution:
The image shows the nits (eggs) of head louse Pediculus capitis, for which the approved treatment is permethrin 1% cream application, repeated after 7 days.

Head louse infestation is very common in children. The majority of the transmission is by head-to-head contact, which is frequently observed with overcrowding(as in schools), poverty, and poor hygiene.

Symptoms include severe itching of the scalp. On examinations, nits are seen, which are firmly attached to hair shafts on which they can be freely glided (as shown in the image below). Adults of lice are difficult to detect.

Treatment :

All infested households and close contacts should be treated at the same time. 1% permethrin lotion is applied to freshly shampooed hair for 10-15 minutes and reshampooed. Nits are removed with a fine-toothed comb. This is repeated after 7 days to kill the newly hatched lice, as permethrin is not ovicidal. Avoid sharing combs, brushes, hair accessories, and towels. To avoid reinfestation, fomites that have been used within 2 days before pediculicide treatment should be washed with hot water and dried with hot air.

Other treatment options include - Malathion 0.5% lotion, ivermectin 0.5% lotion, spinosad 0.9%, gamma benzene hexachloride 1% lotion and abametapir 0.74% lotion.

Other options:

Option A - Oral griseofulvin, for 4-8 weeks is the treatment for tinea capitis.

Option C - Permethrin 5% lotion application, repeated after 7 days is the treatment for scabies.

Option D - Ketoconazole shampoo 2%, applied for 7 days is not a treatment option for pediculosis. Ketoconazole shampoo is used for the treatment of seborrheic dermatitis and tinea versicolor.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male comes with symptoms suggestive of hypothyroidism. Your medicine junior resident proceeds to perform the thyroid examination. During this, he examines the patient as shown in the image below while instructing the patient to swallow. This method is the:
questions.solution:
The image shown depicts Crile’s method of thyroid palpation. In this method, the examiner places the thumb on the thyroid gland and asks the patient to swallow.

Lahey’s method (option B) The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally by the left hand, and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

Kocher’s method (option C) is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Pizzillo’s method (option D) is used for the inspection of the thyroid gland in obese and short-necked individuals. In this method, the hands are placed behind the head and the patient is asked to push his head against the clasped hands.

questions.text: An intern is inserting a central venous catheter through femoral vein in a burns patient. During the procedure, he accidentally injures one of the structures in the femoral sheath. Which of the following structures is not likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The structure unlikely to be injured is the femoral nerve, as it is not the content of the femoral sheath.

The femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment, termed as femoral canal, contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and the lymph node of Cloquet.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old came at 32 weeks of gestation to the antenatal clinic. On per abdomen examination, the fundal height corresponds to 28 cm. Fetal biometry done previously was normal. On USG, abdominal circumference is < 10th percentile of that expected for the POG. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

POG - Period of gestation
questions.solution:
The history of presentation at 32 weeks and examination findings of fundal height less than the period of gestation with previous normal fetal biometry and abdominal circumference < 10th percentile of expected are suggestive of late-onset/ asymmetrical IUGR. The most likely cause of late IUGR is  Utero-placental insufficiency

Asymmetrical IUGR is late-onset and the most common cause is chronic placental insufficiency. 

The fundal height of the uterus corresponds to a period of gestation more than 24 weeks. Fundal height less than period of gestation raises the suspicion of Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Diagnosis of IUGR on USG is made by estimated fetal weight (EFW) < 10th percentile for that period of gestation (or) abdominal circumference (AC) < 10th percentile of expected for that period of gestation. 

Uteroplacental insufficiency can lead to less placental perfusion and therefore less fetal perfusion leading to decreased fetal urine production and thus can cause oligohydramnios. This patient will further need serial evaluation with USG biometry to look for symmetrical or asymmetrical IUGR and UA Doppler to look for fetal perfusion. 

Chromosomal abnormalities, TORCH infections will cause early-onset/ symmetrical IUGR which will be picked up early as 1st or 2nd trimester. 

Duodenal atresia, spinal bifida, tracheo-esophageal fistula are causes of polyhydramnios as they are all associated with open meninges or mucosal surfaces which exclude fluid and cause polyhydramnios which is not expected in case of IUGR.

questions.text: As an intern posted in a PHC, you observe a public water tank disinfected with chlorine. Following this, an orthotolidine-arsenite test is performed. What is/are the parameters measured by this test?
questions.solution:
The parameters measured by the orthotolidine-arsenite test are free and combined chlorine separately.(Option D)

The orthotolidine-arsenite test(OTA) is a modification of the orthotolidine test(OT) that enables to test both free and combined chlorine levels separately. Whereas in an orthotolidine test, free and combined chlorine levels are measured together. 

In addition, the errors caused by the presence of interfering substances such as nitrites, iron and manganese,that produce yellow colour(positive)with an OT test are overcome by the OTA test.

The OT test is performed by adding 0.1 ml of the reagent containing orthotoludine dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid to 1 ml of water to be tested. A yellow colour is produced which is matched against suitable standards or colour discs. Commercial equipment is available for this purpose. It is essential to take the reading within 10 seconds after the addition of the reagent to estimate free chlorine in water. The colour that is produced after a lapse of 15-20 minutes, is due to the action of both free and combined chlorine. (Option C)

The chlorine demand is measured by Horrock’s apparatus. (Option A)

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: An animal rescuer reports to the casualty with a history of being bitten by a stray dog on the hand and bleeding from the wound a few hours ago. He mentioned completing a full pre-exposure rabies vaccination series five years ago. Based on WHO guidelines, what is the treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Administer a complete course of rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin immediately
Give two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3; no need for rabies immunoglobulin
No vaccination or rabies immunoglobulin is necessary due to her prior immunisation
Provide a single booster dose of rabies vaccine immediately and administer rabies immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the correct treatment is administering two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3; no need for rabies immunoglobulin.(Option B)

The given scenario is that of a patient who has completed a documented pre-exposure prophylaxis of rabies vaccination and has sustained a Category III injury (bite with bleeding).

For a person who has previously completed a full pre-exposure vaccination series, WHO guidelines recommend administering two booster doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 following a Category II & III exposure. Rabies immunoglobulin is not required as the patient's previous immunisation provides a base level of immunity that can be quickly enhanced by the booster doses. 

All other general measures such as thorough wound cleansing , chemical treatment with alcohol or povidone iodine, if required delayed suturing of bleeding wounds, anti-tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotic cover when indicated should be followed.

Other options -

Option A) She does not need a complete course of rabies vaccine nor rabies immunoglobulin because she has been previously vaccinated. Only booster doses are required.

Option C)Despite her prior immunisation, booster doses are still required to ensure adequate immunity against the virus following a high-risk exposure.

Option D)There is no need for rabies immunoglobulin in this case because her immune system is already primed to respond effectively to the booster doses of the vaccine alone.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the given bone pathology except:
questions.solution:
The given condition is osteoclastoma/giant-cell tumor (GCT). The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL.

The given image shows an abundance of multinucleated giant cells with a background of mononuclear stromal cells. GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL, which promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue. Sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

Remember E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: Which of the following is known as pan T antigen?
questions.solution:
Pan T antigens are antigens found on all T cells and include CD2, CD3, CD5 and CD7.

CD4 is present on helper T cells. CD8 is present on cytotoxic T cells.

An intern is having difficulty distinguishing between a leukemoid reaction and chronic myeloid leukaemia. What are the characteristics of leukemoid reaction that can help differentiate it from CML?

choices.text: Patient presents with severe bone pain

questions.solution:
The Differential Leukocyte Count in a leukemoid reaction shows left shift with neutrophils having toxic granulations.

Persistent leukocytosis with cell counts of ≥30,000– 50,000/μL is termed leukemoid reactions. It is a non-malignant condition distinguished by a significant rise in white blood cell count, mimicking leukaemia. It occurs in response to diverse inflammatory conditions, infections, and stressors. In a leukemoid reaction, the circulating neutrophils are usually mature and not clonally derived.

Leukocytosis stems from the rapid release of granulocytes from the bone marrow, induced by cytokines like TNF and IL-1. This results in an elevation of both mature and immature neutrophils in the blood, termed a left shift.

Causes of leukemoid reaction include:

  • Severe infections
  • Malignancy (Solid tumours )
  • Severe hemorrhage
  • Acute hemolysis
  • Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)
  • Asplenia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis

A high LAP score with a mature neutrophils further corroborates this diagnosis.

Elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) scores are observed in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions.

CML is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors

questions.text: An adolescent boy was given iron supplements for microcytic hypochromic anemia, however, he did not show clinical improvement. Investigations revealed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, Mentzer index <13, and elevated levels of HbA2 and HbF. Which of the following is the curative treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings of Mentzer index < 13 and elevated levels of HbF and HbA2 in a patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia are suggestive of β-thalassemia major. The curative treatment for β-thalassemia major is hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

MCV/RBC count also known as the Mentzer index. It can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA), both of which have low MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin). 

Mentzer index is

  • More than 13 in iron deficiency anemia- because of lower RBC count
  • Less than 13 in thalassemia- because RBC count is usually normal

Thalassemias are inherited disorders of hemoglobin. There is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. It primarily affects people of Mediterranean origin.

Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly leading to abdominal distension. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen. 

Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. Elevated HbA2 levels are seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis.

The image given below shows peripheral smear findings in thalassemia:


An X-ray of the skull shows a crewcut appearance due to expansion of hematopoetically active marrow.

Thalassemia is usually managed by blood transfusions every 2-4 weeks and chelation therapy with deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone for iron chelation. Splenectomy is indicated when the transfusion requirement to maintain ideal hemoglobin increases. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only known curative treatment for thalassemia.

Other options:

Option A: Iron chelation therapy (oral/parenteral) to prevent organ damage from iron overload. The drugs used are deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone. It is not a curative therapy.

Option B: Blood transfusion should be started at an early age to promote growth and prevent deformities. This provides symptomatic improvement, but it is not a curative treatment.

Option D: Splenectomy is performed in patients with hypersplenism. Patients who have undergone splenectomy are susceptible to infections from capsulated organisms and should receive appropriate vaccinations. It is less preferred due to serious adverse effects. 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.
