questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with long-standing diabetes presents with complaints of lower backache. An x-ray image of her spine is given below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image represents rugger jersey spine which is characteristic of hyperparathyroidism seen in renal osteodystrophy.

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.


Radiographic changes in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Subperiosteal bone resorption: Classically affects the radial aspects of the proximal and middle phalanges of the second and third fingers
  • Terminal tuft erosion of phalanges (acroosteolysis)
  • Rugger Jersey spine
  • Osteopenia
  • Brown tumors
  • Salt and pepper sign in the skull (pepperpot skull)

Note: Paget's disease and osteopetrosis are potential differentials for rugger jersey spine but this term and pattern are distinctive for hyperparathyroidism. The clinical scenario with a history of long-standing diabetes makes the diagnosis of chronic kidney disease renal osteodystrophy more likely.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with papules and pustules on the background of erythema and telangiectasia, affecting her forehead, cheeks, nose and chin. There are no comedones and the periorificial areas are spared. What is the effective management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical stem points to the diagnosis of papulopustular rosacea, which is treated with topical metronidazole.

Rosacea is a dermatological condition, commonly seen in middle-aged females. The exact etiology is not known but abnormal vascular activity and infection with follicular mite Demodex follicorum are suspected.

Lesions are mainly distributed in the centrofacial region - on cheeks, forehead, nose, and chin with sparing of the periorbital and perioral areas.

The following subtypes are seen:

  • Erythmetotelangeictatic type - photosensitive skin with episodes of flushing and edema precipitated by hot drinks, spicy foods, alcohol and stress
  • Papulopustular type - erythematous dome-shaped papules, papulopustules on the background of erythema and telangiectasia. There are no comedones, which helps it distinguish from acne.
  • Phymatous type - Seen in males, where it manifests as rhinophyma (bulbous nose)
  • Ocular rosacea - Patient complains of photophobia and frequent styes, and may develop keratitis and iritis

Management :

Avoid triggers like hot drinks, spicy food, alcohol; use sunscreens for photoprotection

Topical treatment (for mild to moderate cases) -

  •  Metronidazole , retinoic acid - effective against papules and pustules 
  •  Brimonidine - effective against erythema 
  • Tacrolimus, pimecrolimus

Systemic treatment - Doxycycline, isotretinoin

CO2 laser excision for advanced rhinophyma

Steroids, especially topical, should be avoided as withdrawal triggers acute episodes.

Other options :

Option A - Topical benzoyl peroxide is used in the treatment of acne, where it exerts an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory action. In contrast to rosacea, acne presents in adolescents. Along with papules, pustules, and nodules, comedones are always present, on a background of greasy skin.

Option B - Hydroxychloroquine is used in the treatment of chronic discoid lupus erythematosus(DLE) and acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (ACLE). DLE presents with erythematous plaques with follicular plugging and adherent scales, while ACLE presents with a photosensitive butterfly rash affecting the malar region of the face and nose, typically sparing the nasolabial folds; papules and pustules are rare, and systemic symptoms are frequent.

Option D - Topical hydrocortisone is avoided in rosacea as withdrawal triggers acute episodes. It is however used in the treatment of a wide variety of other dermatological conditions, like atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following feature in the fundus of myopic patients, is most likely to predispose them to the development of retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
The presence of lattice degeneration in the fundus of myopic patients predisposes them to the development of retinal detachment.

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is much more common in high myopia. The presence of the following findings at an increased frequency in myopes predisposes them to the development of retinal detachment.

  • Posterior vitreous detachment
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Asymptomatic atrophic holes
  • Myopic macular holes
  • Giant retinal tears

Other fundus features of pathological myopia:

  • Lacquer cracks - They are ruptures in the RPE-Bruch membrane-choriocapillaris complex and appear as fine irregular yellow line crisscrossing at the posterior pole. They can lead to choroidal neovascularization.
  • Coin haemorrhages - They develop from lacquer cracks
  • Fuchs spot - It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion developed at the macula after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed
  • Pale tessellated appearance of the fundus
  • Myopic crescent - in the temporal retina

questions.text: A patient is placed in the following position for surgery. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be the indication for the surgery?
questions.solution:
The surgical position depicted is the modified lateral position, more commonly called the kidney position, therefore the most likely indication  is renal cell carcinoma. 

The position increases the distance between the costal margin and the iliac bone to increase the surgeon's working area in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. This is achieved by angulating the table with the summit near the middle of the table and the two ends sloping away.


Spinal cord pathologies are usually done in the prone position.(Option A)

Gastric adenocarcinoma is done in the supine position in an open approach and in a laparoscopic approach it is done in the reverse Trendelenberg position. In a reverse Trendelenberg position, the head end of the table is tilted up, placing the head higher than the feet. It is usually used in laparoscopic abdominal surgeries.(Option C)

Procedures for varicose veins such as stripping of great saphenous vein, laser ablation and radiofrequency ablation require the patient to be in the Trendelenberg position. The head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed, thereby the head end is at a lower level than the foot end. It is also used in some pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock.(Option D)

Related Pearl: Patient Positioning in Operation Theatre

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A patient presented with lateral gaze palsy in the left eye, with ataxia of the left arm and leg.  He also has paralysis of the right arm, legs, and face, along with loss of touch sensation and proprioception over the right side of the body. Where is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of medial pontine syndrome, which occurs due to a lesion located at the medial pons.

The medial pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the paramedian branch of the basilar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestation
    • CN VI: Diplopia (lateral rectus muscle paralysis - the affected eye looks downwards and inwards)
    • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait
  • Contralateral manifestation
    • Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract: Paralysis of face, arm, and leg
    • Medial lemniscus: loss of touch and proprioception from the body.

The lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: A middle-aged lady was referred to a dermatology clinic for a lesion on her left cheek as shown in the image below. On diascopy, apple jelly nodules were seen. Skin biopsy showed tubercles with absent central caseation surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes in the superficial dermis.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows numerous reddish-brown papules with an elevated scaly surface and scarring. These lesions, together with the features of apple jelly nodules on diascopy and tubercles with absent central caseation, point towards a diagnosis of lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis which occurs in previously sensitized individuals. The characteristic lesion is a plaque, consisting of soft, reddish-brown papules. It grows by slow peripheral extension, becoming discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The lesions are acquired either by hematogenous spread or by direct inoculation. 

There are five clinical variants of lupus vulgaris:

  • Plaque form
  • Ulcerative and mutilating forms
  • Vegetating form
  • Tumor-like forms
  • Papular and nodular form

On diascopy, characteristic 'apple jelly nodules' are seen. Histology shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells, present in the superficial dermis. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent. Treatment is by standard multidrug antituberculosis therapy.

Complications include scarring, contractures, and tissue destruction. Malignant changes (most commonly, squamous cell carcinomas) are known to arise in longstanding lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris- Lesions are due to inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit. It can present with open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules, and nodules.

Option C: Tuberculoid leprosy- Typical lesions are erythematous, copper-colored, or purple plaques, with raised edges sloping towards a hypopigmented center.

Option D: Discoid lupus erythematosus: It is an inflammatory disorder of the skin. The lesions are characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for the diagnosis of amyloidosis?

choices.text: Congo red stain shows apple green birefringence on normal microscopy
Electron microscopy shows  continuous branching fibrils
Light microscopy shows  amorphous eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance
X ray crystallography shows  cross alpha pleated sheet conformation

questions.solution:
The correct statement is light microscope shows amorphous eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance 

Amyloidosis refers to the accumulation of misfolded proteins. Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance. The adsorbed proteins contain abundant charged sugar groups that give the deposits staining characteristics that resemble starch. Hence, these deposits were called amyloid.

It could be classified as generalized/systemic, primary, secondary, localized, or hereditary amyloidosis.

Diagnosis:

  • Electron microscopy shows continuous non-branching fibrils with a diameter of 7.5 to 10 nm (Option B) 
  •  A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation (Option D) is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.
  • The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining, which imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy (Option A)

questions.text: A factory worker with tuberculosis was started on DOTS (directly observed treatment short course) and is advised to rest. He earns Rs 20,000/- as a monthly income and is eligible for periodic payments under the Employees State Insurance Act scheme. Which benefit does this case fall under?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is diagnosed to have tuberculosis, and thus he is eligible for the extended sickness benefit of the ESI scheme. 

Extended sickness benefit is the leave given up to a maximum period of two years. The diseases for which extended sickness benefits are applied are TB, leprosy, empyema, HIV, malignancies, plegias, etc. During this period, 80 per cent of the wages are paid.

ESI act was amended to provide cash and medical benefits to employees during sickness, maternity, and employment injury. People with monthly earnings up to 21,000 are covered under this scheme. Cash benefits are made through branches and cash offices. The medical benefits are made available through ESI dispensaries, clinics, hospitals, etc. The benefits provided to the insured persons are:

  • Medical benefits - Complete medical care is provided to the insured person and his/ her family members.
  • Sickness benefits - include a periodic cash payment for 91 days to the insured sick person. 70% of the average daily wages is given as the daily rate if the person is under medical treatment. 
  • Enhanced sickness benefit - includes 14 days of leave given for tubectomy and 7 days of leave for vasectomy. The amount payable is equal to the full wages.
  • Maternity benefits - cash payments equal to full wages are paid to the insured person for up to 26 weeks in cases of pregnancy.
  • Disablement benefit - cash payment and free medical treatment are given for temporary or permanent disablements and occupational diseases.
  • Dependant's benefit - if an employment injury causes the death of the insured person, the dependants are eligible for periodic payments.
  • Funeral expenses of Rs 15000 are payable to the dependants.
  • Rehabilitation allowance - the insured person and the family members continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement and retirement.

Note: Directly observed treatment short course (DOTS) is an effective treatment strategy used for tuberculosis. In the intensive phase of the treatment, the patient swallows the drug in the presence of a healthcare worker. During the continuation phase, medicine is issued for a week and only the first dose is swallowed in the presence of a health worker. 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: 90 day glaucoma is seen in:
questions.solution:
90 day glaucoma is seen in central retinal vein occlusion because it typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event.

Central retinal vein occlusions (CRVO) typically affect elderly patients in the sixth or seventh decade of life. Some of the risk factors include :

  • Age >50 years
  • Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma
  • Oral contraceptive pills and hormone replacement therapy
  • Smoking

There are two variants - non-ischemic and ischemic.

Non-ischemic CRVO is the most common clinical variety and presents with unilateral mild to moderate blurring of vision of sudden onset. Relative apparent pupillary defect (RAPD) is absent or very mild. Fundoscopy reveals mild venous congestion and tortuosity, with superficial peripheral flame-shaped hemorrhages.

Ischemic CRVO refers to acute complete occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is characterized by marked sudden visual loss and RAPD is present. Fundoscopy shows massively engorged, congested and tortuous retinal veins. Retinal hemorrhages are massive giving a splashed tomato appearance. Cotton wool spots are numerous and the optic disc shows edema and hyperemia. In the late stages, neovascularization may be seen at the disc or in the periphery.


Complications : 

  • Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occur in about 20% of cases within 3 months (so also called 90 days glaucoma)
  • Vitreous hemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy

Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old obese woman has recently been diagnosed with NASH. She is non-diabetic and non-hypertensive, and she has never consumed alcohol. On evaluation, there is no evidence of cirrhosis and cardiovascular diseases. Which of the following can be considered the first line of treatment for this lady?

NASH: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
questions.solution:
Vitamin E can be considered the first line of treatment in this patient with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Vitamin E is well tolerated and has been shown to modestly improve aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. However, vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic, noncirrhotic NASH patients who are at low risk for cardiovascular disease or prostate cancer. 

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

NASH is characterized by hepatic steatosis, which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation.

Most patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work.

Some patients with NASH may present with right upper quadrant pain owing to the stretching of the liver capsule as a result of hepatomegaly or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance; some may present with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis.

Currently, biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia.

Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of using well water for cooking and consumption presents with vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, there is jaundice, hemoglobinuria, Mees lines on the nails, and features of hypovolemic shock. A toxicology screen is done, and the 24-hour urine sample is found to contain high amounts of a toxin.  Which enzyme of Kreb's cycle will be inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (AKG) of Kreb's cycle is inhibited by this toxin, arsenite (inorganic arsenic salt).

α-Ketoglutarate is a rate-determining intermediate in Kreb's cycle. It has a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism as it acts as a precursor of glutamate and glutamine and promotes protein synthesis.

Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form succinyl-CoA and CO2 with the help of the multienzyme complex, AKG dehydrogenase. This enzyme complex requires the cofactors, thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and coenzyme A.

Arsenite inhibits this decarboxylation reaction and causes the substrate, α-ketoglutarate, to accumulate. 

Arsenic toxicity is either due to inhalation of toxic arsenic gas or chronic consumption of foods cooked in contaminated well water. It presents with malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. There may be hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, hypovolemic shock, and cardiovascular manifestations such as QT prolongation, polymorphous ventricular tachycardia, and congestive cardiomyopathy. Mees lines is a common dermatologic manifestation characterized by transverse white striae on the nail.

Arsenic toxicity is detected by measuring the 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic.


Other options: 

Option A: Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is inhibited by iodoacetate. It is not a part of Kreb's cycle.

Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by fluoroacetate.

Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation with Rh-negative pregnancy undergoes the following analysis. The amniotic fluid bilirubin levels plotted fall in zone 3. Which of the following indicates the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Pregnancy can be continued till term

questions.solution:
The graph shown in the above image is Liley's chart. As the amniotic fluid bilirubin levels fall in zone 3, it indicates that the fetus is severely affected and requires immediate delivery.

Liley's chart helps in the estimation of hemolysis severity and indirect assessment of anemia. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm—ΔOD450.

The chart is divided into 3 zones: 

Liley’s zone I (low zone): Rh-negative fetus or fetus is unlikely to be affected and the pregnancy can be continued till term.

Liley’s zone II (mid zone): Indicates fetal anemia.

  • Repeat amniocentesis after 2 weeks → value upward→ cordocentesis→ hematocrit <30%→ intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks.

Liley’s zone III (high zone): Indicates severely affected fetus and death is imminent.

  • If Pregnancy >34 weeks → delivery.
  • If Pregnancy <34 weeks → cordocentesis → hematocrit < 30% → intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks

questions.text: A young female visits doctor for the following skin lesion in her ear. It started around 2 years ago and has increased in size gradually. She does not give any history of ear piercings. A biopsy of the tumor was performed and it showed a jigsaw puzzle appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the biopsy showing jigsaw puzzle appearance is diagnostic of cylindroma.

This is a skin tumor that arises from the sweat gland. The lesions are familial and occur due to the mutation of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD.

The tumors appear as multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red in color, and pedunculated. It is mostly seen on the scalp and adjacent skin. These tumors are benign in nature. 

Histopathology will show the tumor lobules arranged in the form of a jigsaw puzzle. They have a thick basal membrane.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.

Below image shows the jigsaw puzzle appearance seen in cylindroma.


Other options

Option A- Basal cell carcinoma commonly occurs in head and neck. They are usually small, translucent or pearly, with raised telangiectatic edges.It has proliferating atypical basaloid cells forming an axis parallel to the epidermal surface. Typical features include palisading of the basal cells.

Below image shows basal cell carcinoma. The cells at the periphery are arranged in palisades.

 


Option C- Hidradenoma is the tumor of the sweat gland. The lesions are usually solitary and are most likely to be found on the scalp, face, anterior trunk, and upper limbs. Rare sites include the vulva, breast, and external ear. It is lobulated and has two cell types. Polygonal clear cells and smaller darker cells. 

Below image is hidradenoma of vulva


Option D- Spiradenoma is a benign tumor of the sweat gland. It is commonly seen in front of the trunk and upper limbs. The lesion is usually solitary and painful and consists of a firm rounded bluish dermal nodule. The tumor is lobular and contains larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery.

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and features of right heart failure. He also gives a history of sudden cardiac death in his brother. His ECG is given below. The marked changes in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The changes marked in ECG show a notched deflection at the end of the QRS complex due to delayed ventricular activation known as an epsilon wave. It is commonly seen in patients with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterised by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

The patients usually present with rhythm disturbances, right-sided heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy and hyperkeratosis of the palmar and the plantar surfaces. 

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis. In ARVC, there is T inversion and delayed ventricular activation manifesting as epsilon waves.


Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 


Option C: Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia, hypercalcemia, brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, or idiopathic ventricular fibrillation. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.


Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium.

questions.text: Out of two athletes 'A' and 'B', 'A' is participating in long-distance running, and 'B' is participating in the long jump. Which of the following are the correct combination of the muscles and the type of muscle fiber that serves them best?
questions.solution:
'A' is the long-distance runner who would be best benefitting from soleus's slow-twitch fibers, and B, the long jumper would benefit from gastrocnemius's fast-twitch fibers.

Fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers

  • Fast-twitch fibers can deliver extreme amounts of power for a few seconds to a minute.
    • The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibers.
    • Fast-twitch fibers are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibers.
    • Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher preponderance of fast-twitch fibers, which gives it the capability of forceful and rapid contraction of the type used in jumping.
  • Slow-twitch fibers are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobic energy.
    • They have far more mitochondria than do the fast-twitch fibers.
    • They contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion of oxygen throughout the fiber.
    • The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibers.
    • The number of capillaries is greater in the vicinity of slow-twitch fibers.
    • Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibers and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

questions.text: A patient with a clinical triad of areflexia, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia is diagnosed with Miller-Fisher syndrome. Identify the principal glycolipid antibody implicated in this syndrome.
questions.solution:
The principal glycolipid antibody implicated in Miller-Fisher syndrome is the Gq1b antibody.

Miller-Fisher syndrome is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome(GBS). Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness. It classically presents as a triad of:

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia
  • Ophthalmoplegia

The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside GQ1b.

The prognosis in Miller Fisher syndrome is usually good with recovery beginning within 2 to 4 weeks of the symptom onset, and completing by 6 months. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. Relapses are rare.

Treatment for Miller-Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient comes with chronic right shoulder pain. While examining the patient, the following test elicits weakness in the right shoulder. Which of the following muscles/tendons is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the image is the Empty can test and the muscle/tendon implicated here is the supraspinatus.

In this test, the patient is asked to resist the downward force by the examiner, when the arms are in the position of 90° abduction, 30° flexion, and complete internal rotation(as if emptying a can, hence the name of the test). The result is positive if the affected side is weaker than the normal side and indicates a tear in the supraspinatus tendon.

 

Other options - 

Option B - Infraspinatus – Resisted external rotation - The patient flexes elbows to 90 degrees and stands holding his/her arm close to the body. The patient then externally rotates both arms while the examiner applies resistance; lack of power on one side signifies weakness of infraspinatus. 

Option C - Teres minor cannot be assessed separately. But it can assessed along with infraspinatus as they both perform external rotation of the shoulder joint. ‘Lag sign’ and the ‘Drop sign’ are used for this purpose.

The lag sign is performed by asking the patient to lift his arms slightly away from the body and place them in maximum external rotation. A positive test is elicited when the patient cannot maintain that position on one side and allows the arm to drift into a more neutral position. This suggests a tear of the infraspinatus, teres minor or supraspinatus. 

The drop sign is similar, here the arm is in 90 degrees of abduction, the elbow flexed to 90 degrees and the arm maximally externally rotated. When the examiner lets go, the patient would normally hold that position, but if the arm ‘drops’, it denotes a positive test

Option D - Subscapularis –Lift-off test - The patient places one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The patient’s hand is lifted off the back and the patient is told to hold it there. The inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness.

questions.text: A weight lifter presented with a swelling over the right side of the neck, which becomes prominent while lifting weights. While compressing over the swelling, a gurgling sound can be heard. Radiological investigations show an air-filled mass with an external component. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of external laryngocele. The treatment for external laryngocele is excision of the swelling. Bryce's sign is the gurgling/hissing sound heard on compression of the swelling.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule of the ventricle.

It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It presents with hoarseness, cough, and if large, causes obstruction of the airway.

Types of laryngocoele are

  •  Internal - confined within the larynx and presents as distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External - the distended saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in the neck. It presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, increasing in size on coughing or performing Valsalva manoeuvres. 
  • Mixed - both external and internal compounds are seen.

Diagnosis is done by indirect laryngoscopy, soft tissue AP and lateral views of the neck x-ray with Valsalva. CT scan helps to find out the extent of the lesion. 

External type is managed by surgical excision through an external neck incision. Internal type is managed by marsupialization and endoscopic carbon dioxide laser resection.

questions.text: You are a medical student examining a slide of nerve tissue. You find neurons with the structure shown in the image given below. In which of the sites are such neurons most likely to be found?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a single process of axons from the cell body that splits into two, of which, both function as axons. This structure is suggestive of a pseudo-unipolar neuron, which is seen in the dorsal root ganglia.

In pseudounipolar neurons, out of the two axons, one goes to the skin or muscles and another to the spinal cord.

Other options:

Options B and C - Motor horn of the spinal cord has motor neurons and the cerebellar cortex predominantly has Purkinje cells. Both these types of neurons are examples of multipolar neurons/cells. They have one axon and many dendrites.

Cerebellar Purkinje cells have an extensive dendritic tree in a single plane. The image below shows Purkinje cells of the cerebellum:

 

The image below shows a spinal motor neuron:

 

Option D- Scarpa's or vestibular ganglion is an example of bipolar neurons.  They have two specialized processes. A dendrite carries information to the cell and an axon that transmits information from the cell. Another example is the bipolar cells of the retina.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has enjoyed playing tennis since childhood. However, recently while playing with his son, he developed dizziness and vertigo-like symptoms along with cramping of his left arm after repeatedly serving the ball with the racket in his left hand. Which large vessel is likely to be stenosed in this man?
questions.solution:
The above scenario of a patient who developed arm cramping, dizziness, and vertigo-like symptoms on repetitive movements of his left arm is likely to have subclavian steal syndrome. 

In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the left subclavian artery is stenosed i.e. at a point proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery (shown in the image below). 

The stenosis depicted above will diminish blood supply to the left upper limb as well as the left vertebral artery. However, due to the presence of abundant collaterals in the circle of Willis the blood supply to the brain will remain unaffected.

The symptoms arise when the patient exercises the left upper limb leading to increased demand in blood supply. In an attempt to meet this demand, the direction of blood flow in the left vertebral artery reverses and the blood supply is derived from the contralateral vertebral artery. 

This reversal and “stealing” of blood from the contralateral vertebral artery results in diminished supply to the basilar artery and thus the brain. Hence the patient presents with symptoms of dizziness and syncopal episodes. Clinically, the affected upper limb will show feeble pulses.

The etiology of this stenosis is most commonly atherogenic and can be diagnosed by duplex ultrasound, CT or MR angiography.

It can be managed with angioplasty or surgical bypass of the occluded segment, although angioplasty with stenting is preferred.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency with syncope. His BP is 80/60 mm Hg, SpO2 is 94%, and respiratory rate is 16 cycles/min. His ECG findings are shown below. He received 3 mg of intravenous atropine, however, there is no improvement in his condition. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows bradycardia (heart rate ~30 bpm) with no relation between the P and QRS waves, suggestive of third-degree AV block. The next best step is immediate transcutaneous pacing.

Symptomatic bradycardia is defined as having a heart rate of less than 50 beats per minute, for which third-degree heart block is one of the causes. In third-degree heart block, there is a complete failure of conduction between the atria and ventricles. As a result, the atria depolarize in response to SA node activity, while a more distal escape rhythm drives the ventricles independently. Depending on the site of the escape rhythm, the QRS complexes may be of a normal width and occur at 40 to 60 bpm or may be widened and occur at slower rates. 

In adults, the most common causes are acute myocardial infarction and chronic degeneration of the conduction pathways with advanced age. As a result of the slow rate, patients frequently experience fatigue, shortness of breath and syncope.

The treatment algorithm for adult bradycardia is as follows : 

Other options: 

Option A - Repeat atropine IV is not the right option. The maximum dose of atropine to be given is 3mg iv, which the patient has already received.

Option B - Amiodarone is not indicated in the treatment of bradycardia, but rather in ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia

Option D - Defibrillation is performed in ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with a 5-month history of diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, anorexia, and weight loss. Pedal edema is noted upon examination. Blood investigations show hypoproteinemia. Upper GI endoscopy reveals the following findings, with gastric aspirate confirming achlorhydria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and upper GI scope showing large, rugal folds in the stomach are suggestive of Menetrier's disease.

Menetrier disease is a type of hypertrophic gastropathy, associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha. It is characterized by prominent mucosal folds of the body and fundus of stomach, with sparing of the antrum. Histologically, massive foveolar hyperplasia (hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosal cells) and a marked reduction in parietal oxyntic and chief cells are noted.

Patients usually present with insidious and progressive epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. 20 - 100% of patients develop a protein-losing gastropathy due to hypersecretion of gastric mucus. Gastric acid secretion is reduced or absent because of decreased parietal cells.

Cetuximab (EGFR inhibitor) is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss despite therapy with this agent.

Other options :

Option A - Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) is another type of hypertrophic gastropathy, characterized by unregulated gastrin release from a gastrinoma, which in turn leads to markedly increased gastric acid secretion from the parietal cells. Peptic ulcer is the most common clinical manifestation due to basal hyperchlorhydria. Endoscopy reveals multiple ulcers. The image below shows multiple distal duodenal ulcers in a patient with ZES.

Option B - Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is a feature of systemic sclerosis, involving the antrum. These subepithelial lesions reflect the diffuse small-vessel vasculopathy of systemic sclerosis and are described as watermelon stomach due to their endoscopic appearance. Patients with GAVE can have recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding, resulting in chronic unexplained anemia.

Option D - Dieulafoy's lesion is an aberrant vessel in the mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect. It is a vascular malformation that is seen along the lesser curvature of the stomach. Clinical features include sudden onset of massive, painless, recurrent hematemesis with hypotension. Endoscopy reveals a dilated submucosal arteriole, that bleeds through a focal mucosal erosion. Recurrent bleeding with spontaneous cessation is common.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 38-year-old female patient with a retroverted uterus. What is the lowest part of the cervix palpated by the examining finger in this case?
questions.solution:
In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downward and forward; therefore, the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or the posterior lip.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backwards; therefore, on vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix felt by the fingers is the anterior lip.

Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of Internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
The angle between the cervix and vagina The angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female gave birth to a newborn baby with evisceration of the bowel as shown in the image given below. Identify the true statement regarding the condition shown.

choices.text: Defect is usually at the umbilicus
Most common associated anomaly is intestinal atresia
This defect cannot be diagnosed prenatally.
Definitive surgery is done in one sitting.

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of gastroschisis and intestinal atresia is the most common anomaly associated with it. As the herniated bowel contents are not covered by a membrane it is a case of gastroschisis and not omphalocele where the herniated content is completely covered by an amniotic membrane or sac.

Gastroschisis represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. The abdominal defect is located usually to the right of the umbilicus at the junction of the umbilicus and normal skin. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. It is usually <4cm in size without an overlying sac as seen in omphalocele.

Gastroschisis is commonly associated with intestinal atresia. The intestine is thickened, edematous and foreshortened in gastroschisis as the intestine is directly exposed to the amniotic fluid in utero due to the absence of an overlying sac. 

Gastroschisis can be diagnosed by a prenatal ultrasound scan. 

Below is the prenatal ultrasound image showing irregular loops of bowel outside the abdominal cavity without an overlying sac. 

Treatment: All newborns with gastroschisis require urgent surgical treatment. IV fluids are administered to counter the significant evaporative fluid losses. The reduction of the bowel is staged using a silo-plastic bag that is attached to the abdominal wall containing the herniated bowel that is gently reduced every 12-24 hours. Surgical closure can be done within approximately 1 to 2 weeks. 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where the bowel and the solid viscera are covered by the peritoneum and amniotic membrane. It occurs from a small size with intestinal contents to giant omphaloceles which have >4 cm abdominal wall defect.

Omphaloceles can be associated with other syndromes such as exstrophy of the cloaca (vesicointestinal fissure), Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (macroglossia, macrosomia, hypoglycemia, visceromegaly and omphalocele) and Cantrell's Pentalogy (lower thoracic wall malformations, ectopia cordis, epigastric omphalocele, anterior midline diaphragmatic hernia and cardiac anomalies). 

Treatment: Immediate treatment includes attending to the vital signs and maintaining the body temperature. Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in case a rupture of the sac occurs. Small-medium sized defects have a better prognosis. In cases of large-sized defects, primary repair of the omphalocele is attempted if the pulmonary status is satisfactory.

Below is the image of an infant with omphalocele.

questions.text: In states that have an annual parasite index of less than 1 case per 1000 populations at risk, health workers are advised to carry out active and/or passive case detection for early detection and treatment of all cases of malaria. This strategy to interrupt the transmission of disease is an example of?
questions.solution:
The strategy to interrupt the transmission of disease in specific regions is an example of disease elimination.

Elimination is the process of interrupting the transmission of a disease and regional elimination is an important precursor for eradication. In this scenario, health workers were advised to carry out active and/or passive case detection in states with an annual parasite index of less than 1 case per 1000 populations at risk. This is done for early detection and treatment of all cases of malaria as interrupting the transmission of malaria, leads to regional disease elimination. 

Other options:

Option A: Tertiary prevention is defined measures that are taken to prevent complications and allow rehabilitation in people who have already developed advanced stages of a disease.

Option B: Primordial prevention is measures taken to prevent the development of the risk factors for disease in a population group they haven't emerged.

Option C: Eradication of disease implies termination of all transmission of infection by the extermination of the infectious agent. It implies the cessation of infection and disease from the whole world.

questions.text: Which of the following lipid metabolic pathways is correctly matched with their rate-limiting enzyme?

choices.text: Ketone body synthesis - cytosolic HMG CoA synthase
Fatty acid β oxidation - Acetyl CoA carboxylase

questions.solution:
The correctly matched lipid metabolic pathway with its rate-limiting enzyme is bile-acid synthesis - 7α hydroxylase. It converts cholesterol into 7α hydroxycholesterol.

The activity of the enzyme is regulated by negative feedback mainly via the nuclear bile acid–binding receptor, farnesoid X receptor (FXR). When the size of the bile acid pool(mainly chenodeoxycholic acid) in the enterohepatic circulation increases, FXR is activated and transcription of 7α hydroxylase is suppressed. Whereas, 7α hydroxylase activity is enhanced by endogenous and dietary cholesterol. 

The rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis is HMG CoA reductase. Cytosolic HMG CoA synthase is involved in cholesterol synthesis whereas mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketone body synthesis. (Options A and B)

The fatty acid oxidation in our body predominantly occurs by β oxidation and the rate-limiting step is carnitine palmitoyl-transferase-I (CPT-I) present in the outer mitochondrial membrane. It helps transport an activated fatty acid (Acyl CoA) inside the mitochondria from the cytosol by binding to carnitine. (Option D)       

Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting step of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: An intern was asked to observe a histological section of the esophagus. What type of cells are seen by him in the basal layer of the epithelium of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the esophagus is the stratified squamous epithelium. The basal layer of cells present in the stratified squamous epithelium is composed of columnar cells.

The stratified squamous epithelium is made up of several layers of cells:

  • The cells in the deepest layer of the epithelium are columnar
  • The cells in the middle layers are polygonal
  • The cells in the superficial layers are flattened squamous cells

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text:
A patient from Bihar came with complaints of fever, weight loss and darkened skin of hands and feet. On examination, splenomegaly is present and rk39 antigen is positive. Which of the following drugs is given orally as directly observed treatment(DOT) according to the NVBDCP programme?

NVBDCP - National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, weight loss, darkened skin of hands and feet with splenomegaly and rk39 antigen positive suggests a diagnosis of Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis. According to the NVBDCP, the oral drug given as a directly observed treatment(DOT) to a patient with Kala-azar is miltefosine.(Option C)

Miltefosine is a relatively safe oral drug used for the treatment of Kala-azar. The treatment is provided as Directly Observed Treatment (DOT) with patient coding system being followed with respect to body weight of the patient. Miltefosine is given in the available strengths of 10mg and 50mg once daily or twice daily for 28 days.

It is the drug of choice in cases of post Kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL). Miltefosine 100mg/day for 12 weeks is the standard treatment.It is contraindicated in pregnancy, breastfeeding and in women who refuse contraception during miltefosine treatment.

Intravenous Liposomal Amphotericin B of dose 10mg/kg is the usual first line treatment for Kala-azar due to its high efficacy, safety, ease of use and assured compliance.(Option A)

Paromomycin intramuscular injection is indicated in combination with miltefosine as 2nd line drug to Amphotericin B.(Option B)

Clofazimine is used as a Group B drug in multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis(MDR-TB) treatment and in multibacillary leprosy treatment. It is not used in paucibacillary leprosy.(Option D)

Note: The central government has approved a new treatment regimen for paucibacillary (PB) leprosy. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has introduced a 3-drug regimen for PB leprosy instead of a 2-drug regimen. This revised drug regimen will be applicable in India from April 1, 2025.

questions.text: During your pharmacology viva, The examiner gives a scenario where 2 persons "A" and "B" diagnosed with type 1  and type 2 diabetes, respectively, need to be treated with the same glucose-lowering agent. Which of the following agents would you pick for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Pramlintide can be used in both Type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus. It is a synthetic analogue of amylin.

Islet amyloid peptide (amylin) is produced from pancreatic beta-cell. It acts in specific regions of hindbrain resulting in a reduction in glucagon release, delayed gastric emptying, and satiety. It is approved for the treatment of types 1 and 2 diabetes as an adjunct in patients who take insulin with meals. The most common adverse effects are nausea and hypoglycemia.

Exenatide, Liraglutide, and Tolbutamide are not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus. Because the beta cells are already destroyed in Type 1 DM and there is no role of any insulin secretagogues or any drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with painful vesicular eruptions localized to the tip of her nose and right eyelid. She also complains of right-sided eye pain, redness, and watering. A provisional diagnosis of Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is made. According to Hutchinson's rule, which of the following structures is involved in this patient?

VZV: Varicella Zoster Virus
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of herpes zoster ophthalmicus characterized by a unilateral painful, vesicular rash involving the nose and eyelid, and with ocular manifestations of pain, redness, and watering. Hutchinson's rule states that ocular involvement is frequent if the side or tip of the nose presents with vesicles, due to the involvement of the nasociliary nerve.

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is caused by the reactivation of VZV within the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve. Upon reeactivation, it travels in an antegrade fashion to the skin and eyes to cause the typical manifestations.

Mechanisms of ocular involvement:

  • Direct viral inflammation leads to conjunctivitis and epithelial keratitis.
  • Secondary and occlusive vasculitis may cause uveitis, keratitis, epicleritis and scleritis. Optic neuritis and cranial nerve palsies may also be seen.
  • Cicatrizing processes may occur following severe eyelid, particular skin and conjunctival involvement. Reactivation causes necrosis and inflammation the sensory ganglia causes corneal anaesthesia and neurotrophic keratopathy.

Corneal involvement is known as zoster keratitis. Involvement of corneal epithelium results in superficial punctate keratitis and pseudo-dendritic/micro-dendritic ulcer. Stromal involvement results in nummular keratitis and disciform keratitis (associated with endothelitis).

Other ocular lesions in herpes zoster include uveitis, episcleritis and scleritis.

The spread is airborne and through fomites and the lesions cease to be infectious when they crust. Age and immunocompromised status are the two most important predisposing factors for this condition because of the diminishing T-cell immunity.

The image below is characteristic of herpes zoster opthalmicus:

Other options: 

Options A and B: The frontal nerve and lacrimal nerve are often involved in herpes zoster ophthalmicus. However, the nerve affected in Hutchinson's rule is the nasociliary nerve.

Option D: Involvement of maxillary nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve is rare in herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It is not related to Hutchinson's rule.

questions.text: A young man presented to the ER with a fever and suppurative lymphadenopathy of his left axilla. The histopathological examination of the axillary node reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the histopathological image showing stellate granuloma point to a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease caused by Bartonella henselae.

The clinical presentation includes a linear pustular lesion at the site of a cat's scratch and regional lymphadenopathy. The reservoir for B. henselae is cat, which infects humans through contact with skin lesions. It is usually self-limited and treated symptomatically with analgesics and drainage of excessively large lymph nodes. Azithromycin helps shorten the recovery period and lymph node swelling. 

It is also associated with bacillary angiomatosis, which are vascular tumors that appear as red papules on the skin, mucosa, and other locations, which resemble Kaposi sarcoma and bacillary peliosis involving the liver and spleen.

Cat-scratch disease is also known as subacute regional lymphadenitis. 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

questions.text: You are conducting a study to compare the mean systolic blood pressures of two groups the diabetic and non-diabetic patients.  Each group has 30 randomly selected patients, and the data are normally distributed. Which statistical test should you use to compare the mean systolic blood pressures of these two groups?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the unpaired t-test would be performed to compare the means of two independent groups when the data is normally distributed. In the study, the groups are independent (diabetic patients vs. non-diabetic patients), and you are comparing the means of a continuous variable (systolic blood pressure), making the unpaired student t-test/ independent samples t-test the best choice.

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. 

Other options:

Option A: Chi-square test is used for categorical data to test the relationship between two categorical variables or to compare observed data with data expected based on a hypothesis. It is not suitable for comparing means of continuous variables. It is used to differentiate proportions in two or more groups and assess the significance.

Option C: One-way ANOVA is used to compare the means of three or more independent groups. Since you are only comparing two groups, the t-test is more appropriate.

Option D: Pearson correlation coefficient is used to measure the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. It does not apply to comparing group means.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: You are volunteering for the medical humanitarian service organization in Ghana. A patient comes with complaints of marked eye redness and pain. You note hemorrhages, as shown below. Which of the following organisms cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above history of marked red-eye and pain along with hemorrhages, as shown in the image, is suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which is caused by enterovirus 70 (picornavirus).

Enterovirus 70 is an RNA virus. This disease was an epidemic in the far East and Africa and was known as epidemic hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 

Patients complain of marked pain, redness, photophobia, and watering. On examination, conjunctival congestion and subconjunctival hemorrhage, as well as periauricular lymphadenopathy, can be noted.

The disease is self-limiting, however, antibiotics may be given to prevent secondary infection. 

Other options:

Option B: Chlamydia trachomatis is the causative agent of adult inclusion conjunctivitis and trachoma. Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis that is characterized by a mix of follicular and papillary conjunctivitis, pannus formation, and cicatrization in later stages. Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is characterized by acute follicular conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge.

Option C: Herpes simplex type 1 causes herpetic conjunctivitis and is typically unilateral follicular conjunctivitis with/without vesicular lesions on the face and/or eyelids. Most patients show preauricular lymph node enlargement.

Option D: Moraxella axenfield causes angular bacterial conjunctivitis. These patients present with foamy-white discharge and redness near the angles of the eye.

questions.text:
A menopausal woman with hot flashes is being considered for an oral combined HRT. Presence of which other factor would not be a contraindication to initiating the treatment?

HRT - Hormone Replacement Therapy

choices.text: Known case of hypertension, controlled on medication
History of right mastectomy for breast cancer, currently on chemotherapy
One episode of deep vein thrombosis, managed medically
History of myocardial infarction, managed medically

questions.solution:
HRT can be initiated in a known case of hypertension, controlled on medication.

Hormone replacement therapy(HRT) is available in the form of estrogen, progesterone and combination preparations. They can be taken orally, as transdermal patches, or as vaginal formulations. The indications for its use are:

  • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency (post-menopausal females)
  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents(eg. Turner’s syndrome)
  • Premature menopause - either spontaneous or following surgery(oophorectomy or hysterectomy/tubectomy when blood supply to the ovaries is compromised)
  • Menopause caused by radiotherapy and chemotherapy for cancer

Contraindications for the use of HRT are:

  • Known, suspected or history of breast cancer, uterine cancer
  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or prior stroke, myocardial infarction or transient ischemic attack
  • Untreated hypertension
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Known thrombophilia
  • Active liver diseases

Hypertension, diabetes and smoking are not contraindications, provided they are regularly monitored. 

In cases where HRT is contraindicated, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (paroxetine), clonidine, gabapentin and pregabalin can be used to treat hot flashes.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being taken up for cholecystectomy. Which anesthetic agent would be ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent that is ideal for a patient with liver disease is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent (has a rapid recovery profile and is not irritating to airways). 

The hepatic effects of volatile anesthetics are caused by alterations in liver perfusion. Hepatic arterial buffer response (HABR) is an autoregulatory mechanism of hepatic blood flow. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane. Thus, sevoflurane is not known to cause hepatotoxicity. 

Other options:

Option B: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that has been used for maintenance but it can cause fulminant hepatic necrosis known as halothane hepatitis. 

Option C: Midazolam is an intravenous anesthetic. Its elimination is reduced in liver disease leading to an increased sedating effect.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is also an intravenous anesthetic that has reduced elimination in patients with liver dysfunction.

questions.text: A 9 month-old baby is brought to the casualty unresponsive. Which of the following techniques of chest compressions is the best to be followed in two-rescuer CPR?

choices.text: Two thumbs over sternum, just below nipple line
Base of one hand over sternum , just below nipple line
Index and middle finger over sternum, just below nipple line
Thumb of one hand over sternum, just below nipple line

questions.solution:
In two rescuer CPR technique for infants, the infant's torso is encircled with both hands, thumbs pointing towards head and positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum.

Chest compressions in infants are given by placing two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below it, if only one provider is available.

If the infant doesn’t have a pulse:

  • Begin 5 cycles of CPR (lasts approximately 2 minutes).
  • Start with Chest Compressions:
  • Provide 100 to 120 compressions per minute. This is 30 compressions every 15 to 18 seconds.
  • If there is only one provider, Place two fingers on the sternum of the lower chest. One between the nipple line and the other 1cm below.
  • If there are two providers, encircle the infant’s torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum.
  • Chest Compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of infant’s chest.
  • Allow for full chest recoil.
  • Only allow minimal interruptions to the chest compressions.


(One Provider: 1 cycle is 30 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths) (Two Providers: 1 cycle is 15 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths)

The correct sequence to provide basic life support is to assess responsiveness, check for breathing and pulse, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and then start bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with an itchy rash along the extensor surface of her elbows, knees, and scalp. Examination reveals pink plaques with overlying silvery scales. She also has new lesions as shown in the image. The phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas is known as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image describe plaque psoriasis on the dorsum of the hand and isomorphic or Koebner phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas.

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants, or any treatment procedures. It is commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, lichen sclerosus, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and vitiligo.

Other option:

Option B - Development of lesions seen as a result of the spread of an infective agent (like Molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), is called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Option C - If a lesion disappears at the site of injury/trauma, then it is termed as the "reverse Koebner phenomenon". It has been documented in cases of psoriasis and vitiligo.

Option D - The isotopic phenomenon is the occurrence of a new skin disorder at the site of another healed skin condition. For example, the appearance of psoriasis at contact dermatitis or the appearance of granuloma annulare at the site of herpes zoster.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man presents with complaints of swelling over the abdomen as seen in the image below. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows shrunken liver. The blood flow in these veins is away from the umbilicus. The cause of the distended veins seen in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcohol-associated cirrhosis of the liver. The clinical finding of dilated veins, as seen in the image is known as caput-medusae which occurs due to portal hypertension.

Caput medusae refer to the dilated superficial veins that are present around the umbilicus. It is one of the major sites of portocaval anastomoses in portal hypertension, where these anastomoses open up to form dilated veins radiating from the umbilicus.

Portal hypertension is characterized by an elevated hepatic venous pressure gradient. The usual complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, hypersplenism (splenomegaly), and ascites.

The most common cause of portal hypertension is liver cirrhosis. Liver cirrhosis causes increased resistance to blood flow within the liver resulting in elevated portal pressure.

Clinically, patients with alcoholic liver disease present with jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider naevi, finger clubbing, asterixis, gynecomastia, and Dupuytren's contracture.

The illustrated image given below shows caput medusae around the umbilicus:

 

Other options:

Option B: Hypoalbuminemia in liver cirrhosis causes ascites due to reduced oncotic pressure and leukonychia (white discoloration of nails). The image given below shows leukonychia.

 

Option C: Inferior vena cava obstruction can occur secondary to deep venous thrombosis, malignancy, pregnancy, or infection. Patients usually present with symptoms of decreased venous return such as fatigue, dizziness, and shortness of breath.

questions.text: A traveller who was lost in a desert during his travel could not drink water for one day. He started to have symptoms of dehydration. Which change would you expect to find in this person?

choices.text: Increased water permeability of the ascending loop of Henle
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

questions.solution:
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct will be expected in a dehydrated person deprived of water for 24 hours.

Dehydration due to water deprivation causes an increase in extracellular osmolality. This in turn signals the osmoreceptors and stimulates the increase in the plasma levels of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This leads to increased permeability of water in the late distal tubules, and cortical and medullary collecting ducts. This further results in the formation of a small volume of concentrated urine, thereby correcting the extracellular fluid osmolality. 

The increased ADH increases the water permeability in the collecting ducts but the ascending loop of Henle is relatively impermeable to water. This low permeability is not altered by water deprivation or increased levels of ADH.
