questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter to the outpatient department with concerns about early breast development in the child. All of the following conditions could have caused precocious puberty in this child, except ________.
questions.solution:
All of the listed options present with precocious puberty, except Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with delayed puberty.

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include neonatal hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

Precocious puberty is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and 9 years in males. Precocious puberty with secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, and that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender (such as virilization in girls) is termed contrasexual.

Isosexual precocious puberty can be categorized as follows:

  • Complete - This occurs due to the premature activation of the intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. The causes of complete isosexual precocious puberty, which is GNRH-dependent include the following:
    • Idiopathic true precocious puberty
    • Central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas, encephalitis, and brain abscess
  • Incomplete - This includes premature thelarche and premature adrenarche. The causes of incomplete isosexual precocious puberty are as follows:
    • GnRH-secreting tumors
    • Increased androgen secretion by adrenal or testis such as in congenital adrenal hyperplasia
    • Ovarian cysts and estrogen-secreting ovarian or adrenal neoplasms
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

Contrasexual precocial puberty can be seen in both males and females:

  • Feminization in males due to conditions such as adrenal neoplasms and chorioepithelioma
  • Virilization in females due to conditions such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenal neoplasms, and iatrogenic exposure to androgens

questions.text: A young male presents with symptoms of arthralgia, weight loss, malaise, and new-onset headache. Upon examination, his blood pressure is 190/120 mm Hg. Following thorough evaluation, a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa is established. Which of the following complications would not be expected in this disease condition?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary artery hypertension is not a complication of polyarteritis nodosa.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic vasculitis of the small and medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels, but sparing the pulmonary arteries. 

The vascular lesion in PAN is a segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation, which tends to involve bifurcations and branching of arteries. Fibrinoid necrosis ensues with compromise of the lumen, thrombosis and infarction of the tissues supplied by the vessel. Granulomas are not observed.

30% of patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B and deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes in the affected vessels.

Non-specific symptoms like fever, weight loss and malaise are present in over one-half of cases.

Specific complaints related to a particular organ system may also dominate the clinical picture:

  • Renal - renal failure, hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal - arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
  • Peripheral nervous system - Peripheral neuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Abdominal pain, bleeding, bowel infarction and perforation
  • Skin - rash, purpura, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Cardiac - Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, pericarditis
  • Genitourinary - Testicular, ovarian or epididymal pain
  • Central nervous system - Cerebral vascular accident, seizure, altered mental status

Death usually results from gastrointestinal complications, particularly bowel infarcts and perforation, and cardiovascular causes.

Diagnosis - The diagnosis is based on the demonstration of characteristic findings of vasculitis on biopsy material. An elevated ESR is almost always present. All patients should be screened for hepatitis B and C. 

Treatment - Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide have shown favorable results. In patients with hepatitis B, antiviral therapy is used in combination with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange.

questions.text: A young man with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago, is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks. His weakness began in the toes and ankles and progressed to involve his knee and hip joints. His upper limbs are not affected and cranial nerves are intact. On examination, there is an absent knee jerk. Which of the following would you consider as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). Intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) would be considered as the initial therapy in this patient.

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. Most of the cases occur after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies are produced against external antigens like infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HHV) and vaccines (Influenza). These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue (called molecular mimicry).

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia) with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves leading the bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

igh-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Other options: 

Option B - Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness. This patient has no bulbar weakness (normal cranial nerves).

Option C - Corticosteroid administration has not been shown to provide many benefits in GBS. 

Option D - Antibiotic administration would not be useful in GBS as the pathophysiology involves axonal degeneration due to a immune cause, not infective. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis

questions.text: The given image illustrates the functional divisions of the cerebellum. Which of the following functions is attributed to the part labeled 2?

choices.text: Maintenance of equilibrium by coordinating with the vestibular apparatus
Coordinating distal limb movement feedback from the propioceptors and cerebral cortex
Planning of sequential movements by communicating with the cerebral cortex
Regulation of body temperature in coordination with the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The area marked 2 represents the spinocerebellum, which is involved in coordinating distal limb movement feedback from proprioceptors and the cerebral cortex.

The functional divisions of the cerebellum include:

  • Vestibulocerebellum - Phylogenetically the oldest part of the cerebellum, it consists of small flocculonodular lobes. It has connections with the vestibular apparatus and is concerned with equilibrium and eye movements (option A).
  • Spinocerebellum - The rest of the vermis and the adjacent medial portions of the hemispheres form the spinocerebellum. This region receives proprioceptive input from the peripheral parts of the body as well as a copy of the motor plan from the motor cortex. By comparing plans with performance, it smoothens and coordinates ongoing movements.
  • Cerebrocerebellum - Comprised of the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres, this is phylogenetically the newest part of the cerebellum, reaching the greatest development in humans. Its main function is the planning of sequential movements. It is not involved in movement happening at a given movement, but what will be happening during the next sequential movement (option C).

Other options : 

Option D - Cerebellum is not involved in the regulation of body temperature, which is the function of the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old homemaker presents with complaints of pain in her right elbow. There is no history of trauma. She finds it particularly difficult to lift objects. On examination, there are no visible findings, however, Cozen’s test is positive. What is the likely site of inflammation?

choices.text: Origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis

questions.solution:
Cozen’s test is positive in lateral epicondylitis, where the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis is involved.

Lateral epicondylitis/tennis elbow is the most common tendinopathy. It is believed to be a degenerative disorder, with pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. Ironically tennis elbow is more common in non-tennis players, especially those involved in household chores like washing, brooming, cooking, etc. which requires repeated extension of the elbow leading to the development of this condition.

The patient complains of pain on the outer aspect of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting, such as lifting a laptop out of a bag, lifting a kettle, or shaking hands. The elbow usually looks normal but slight swelling may be visible. The patient will typically have a full range of movement. 

Examination : 

  • Local tenderness on the outside of the elbow at the common extensor origin with aching pain in the back of the forearm 
  • Cozen’s test - A resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test - A resisted extension of the middle finger elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

X-ray findings in most of the cases are normal. 

Management :       

90% of the cases resolve spontaneously in 12 months.     

  • Non-operative - Activity modification and physiotherapy will speed up recovery. A static wrist splint may help with pain control. Steroid injection will provide short-term pain relief but recurrence rates are high. Autologous blood product injection may have a role.      
  • Operative - If the pain persists despite adequate non-surgical measures, tendon debridement can provide pain relief in approximately 85% of cases. 

Other options : 

Option A - Insertion of biceps tendon is affected in distal biceps tendinopathy. It is seen in individuals going to the gym to lift weights into their forties and fifties. It causes anterior elbow pain which is reproduced on resisted forearm supination. 

Option B - Origin of pronator teres is affected in medial epicondylitis/Golfer's elbow. Tenderness over the medial epicondyle and pain on resisted forearm pronation in extension are diagnostic. 

Option D - Olecranon bursa is affected by bursitis (Student's elbow). The most common non-traumatic cause is gout; there may be a sizeable lump with calcification on X-ray. 

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the autopsy incisions preferred for the given indication?

choices.text: Y incision - Autopsy of female corpse

questions.solution:
The correct representation is Y incision - Autopsy of female corpse. 

Y-shaped incision commences at anterior axillary folds on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards to the symphysis pubis, as in the I-shaped incision. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision, and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

Option A: I-shaped incision is a simple, convenient, and most commonly practiced incision. It extends from the symphysis mentii to the symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left or right around the umbilicus. The umbilicus has dense fibrous tissue and is difficult to penetrate with the needle for suturing after autopsy.

Option B: An elongated X-shaped incision is used to dissect subcutaneous structures in the back of the body. It helps identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries when superficial imprints are faint. This type of incision is helpful in the reconstruction of events before death and is practiced in custodial death.

Option C: In the modified Y-shaped incision, an incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. It is indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: An ENT technician conducts a tympanometry test by sealing the patient's external auditory canal with a probe and emitting a 220Hz signal tone against the tympanic membrane. The above procedure is used to find the diseased status of which of the following:
questions.solution:
The tympanometric test conducted by the ENT technician by sealing the patient's external auditory canal with a probe and emitting a 220Hz signal tone is used for identifying the diseased status of the middle ear or tympano-ossicular system.

Tympanometry is a component of the impedance audiometry which is an objective test of the ear. 

The tympanometry is based on sounds reflected from a stiff tympanic membrane. A more rigid tympanic membrane would reflect a greater amount of sound energy as compared to a flexible one. It determines the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system, thereby assessing the health or disease condition of the middle ear.

The equipment has a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and it has three channels:  

  1. to deliver a tone of 220Hz
  2. to collect the reflected sound waves
  3. To change the air pressure in the ear canal from positive to negative.

Tympanograms are obtained by charting compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against pressure changes. They are diagnostic for graphs for a few middle-ear disorders.

Tympanometry is also used to find the function of the eustachian tube against an intact or perforated tympanic membrane. Patency of grommet is also detected in serous otitis media patients.

Acoustic reflex is used to detect pathologies of the cochlea, 8th nerve, facial nerve, and brainstem by detecting stapedial contraction after passing a loud sound of about 70-100dB above the threshold of a normal ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding and itching. What is the mutation associated with this disease?

choices.text: Mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma.

Nodular basal cell carcinoma presents as a small, slowly growing pearly nodule with rolled borders, often having dilated telangiectatic vessels on its surface, and a central crust. The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

Other options:

Mutations in cell cycle regulators (option A), receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (option B), and those that activate telomerase (option C) are associated with melanomas. They typically appear as irregular, asymmetric macular lesions with variable pigmentation (shades of black, brown, red, dark blue, and gray). They are usually asymptomatic but occasionally are itchy or painful. Clinical signs include changes in the color, size, or shape of a pigmented lesion.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: An annual symposium on diabetes mellitus is being conducted by a medical college. The event would most likely comprise of _______.

choices.text: A series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end
A series of meetings with emphasis on individual work within a group
6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other
4-8 qualified persons  discussing the topic in front of an audience

questions.solution:
A symposium comprises of a series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end.

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions.There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other options:

Option B - A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option C - A group discussion is described as 6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other in a face-to-face manner. Health interventions that involve long-term compliance such as cessation of smoking, obesity reduction; group discussions are considered valuable. There should be a leader to start the subject and to ensure equal participation, preventing side conversations and summarize the subject in the end. A recorder of the discussion is desirable.

Option D - Panel discussions take place with 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. It has a chairman, moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

questions.text: Given image demonstrates the principle of working of a special type of microscope used to study microbial motility. Identify the microscope.
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates the working of phase contrast microscope.

Phase contrast microscope is one in which the contrast of the object under vision is enhanced. The microscope visualises the unstained living cells by creating difference in contrast between the cells and water.

Principle of phase contrast microscope : 

  • As the cone of light passes through a cell, some light rays are bent due to variations in density and refractive index within the specimen and are retarded by about one­ fourth of a wavelength.
  • The undeviated light rays strike a phase ring in the phase plate, while the deviated rays miss the ring and pass through the rest of the plate.
  • The phase ring is constructed in such a way that the undeviated light passing through it is advanced by one­ fourth of a wavelength, the deviated and undeviated waves will be about half wavelength out of the phase and will cancel each other when they come together to form an image.
  • The background, formed by undeviated light, is bright, while the unstained object appears dark and well­ defined.

Phase contrast microscopy is especially useful for studying :

  • Microbial motility
  • Determining the shape of living cells
  • Detecting microbial internal cellular components, such as the cell membrane, nuclei, mitochondria, spindles, chromosomes, Golgi apparatus, endospores and inclusion bodies; which become clearly visible because they have refractive indices markedly different from that of water.

questions.text: A 9-year-old was brought with lesions depicted below. There were complaints of bony pain and early onset of puberty. X ray revealed fibrous dysplasia of proximal part of femur. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of precocious puberty, cafe au lait spots, bony pain and X Ray findings suggests the diagnosis of McCune Albright syndrome.

McCune Albright syndrome presents as a triad of cafe-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. Fibrous dysplasia is the fibrous replacement of cancellous bone as shown below. It can result in bony pain, repeated fractures, and cranial nerve compression. The condition arises due to activating mutations of the GNAS1 gene.

 Cafe-au-lait macules(CALM) are characterized by their flat appearance and uniform brown coloration, typically being about two shades darker than the surrounding skin. Their size can range from 0.5 to over 12 centimeters. Although an individual spot may occur in approximately 10% of the general population, the existence of numerous CALMs suggests the potential presence of an associated genodermatosis, such as neurofibromatosis (NF) or McCune-Albright syndrome. CALM in NF1 generally has regular borders unlike those present in MCCune Albright syndrome.

Radiographic features of fibrous dysplasia include a lytic or ground-glass expansile lesion of the metaphysis or diaphysis.

Other options

Option A: Neurofibromatosis type 1 is autosomal dominant disorder characterised by cafe au lait spots, neurofibromas and pigmented iris hamartomas.

Option C: Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition found in both males and females. It is associated with low IQ, delayed puberty, low fertility, pulmonary stenosis and HOCM.

Option D: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with precocious puberty and fibrous dysplasia.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A concerned mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day-old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below.  Microscopic examination of this lesion revealed neutrophils. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over the arms of a newborn, with the presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is suggestive of transient pustular melanosis.

Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition seen more commonly among African-American neonates than Caucasian neonates. They present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles. The pustular phase lasts for 2-3 days and no therapy is required. However, the subsequent hyperpigmented macules may last for up to 3 months.

Samples from the lesion can be cultured and smears can be prepared. They contain neutrophils and will not contain bacteria or aggregates of eosinophils. This distinguishes these lesions from those of pyoderma and erythema toxicum respectively. More dangerous lesions like the vesicular eruptions of herpes simplex and staphylococcal skin infections need to be ruled out by appropriate testing. 

Other options:

Option B - Mongolian spots are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

Option C - Erythema toxicum is another transient condition characterized by small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.

Option D - Cutis marmorata is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: During the mini mental state examination of a patient in the psychiatry ward, the patient was instructed to place right index finger on his nose and then on his left ear. Which of the following is being evaluated?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, language of the patient is being evaluated in MMSE.

While testing for language, the patient is asked to follow a three step command and scored accordingly. For example, the patient could be asked to take a piece of paper from the table, fold it in half and put it in the floor.

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes to complete. A score of less than 23 points to cognitive impairment.

The components of MMSE are orientation, registration, attention and calculation, recall and language. It can be used to screen for and assess dementia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was admitted to your hospital with multiple pigmented papular lesions on his face, neck, forearm, and corneal injection following the exposure to the sun as shown below.  On further investigations, cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinoma were found. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple lesions on the sun-exposed area and multiple cutaneous malignancies are suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin.

XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

questions.text: A 28-year-old anxious male comes to the urology OPD with a chronic history of deformity of the penis and pain on erection. He is subjected to the USG of the penis, the findings of which are as shown below. Which of the following associated is not a part of the classical Galezia's triad expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the penile calcifications of the corpus cavernosum. Erectile dysfunction is a complication of Peyronie's disease and not a component of Galezia's triad.

Galezia triad conisits of:

  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Dupuytren's contracture 
  • Peyronie's disease

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

The active phase is characterized by changes in penile curvature or deformity and pain with erection. Stable disease is characterized by the absence of pain and nonprogression of deformity. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical examination but MRI may be helpful.

Verapamil intralesional drug therapy and collagenase clostridium histolyticum (CCH) intralesional drug therapy are safe and well tolerated treatment options. Penile traction therapy, usually in conjunction with medical management, has shown some efficacy.

In severe deformity and calcifications, surgical options are preferred. Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend increases during the active phase (18-24 months).  The treatment will shorten the erect penile length.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a rare type of hemolytic anemia that developed after a viral infection and is associated with the presence of Donath-Landsteiner antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of a rare hemolytic anemia that develops after a viral infection and is associated with Donath-Landsteiner antibodies suggests paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH).

PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies (Donath Landsteiner antibodies) directed against the P blood group antigen and brings about complement-mediated hemolysis. It presents as intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria and most cases are seen in children following viral infections. It may be seen in association with tertiary syphilis or as a complication of certain infections such as Mycoplasma pneumonia, flu, measles, and mumps.

In PCH, the direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test will be positive for complement only. It is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

It is a self-limiting condition (recovery within 1 month) but blood transfusion is required for the control of anemia.  

Immuno-hemolytic anemias are of 3 types:

Option A: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG). It is chronic hemolytic anemia that is characterized by intravascular hemolysis. Apart from hemolysis, other features like pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are also seen. Patients may present with the passage of blood in urine, recurrent abdominal pain, and anemia which is normal-macrocytic.

Option C: March hemoglobinuria is an acute and self-imposed condition in which the RBCs lose their deformability and succumb to wear and tear leading to intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

Option D: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia disorders are characterized by microvascular lesions due to the deposition of platelets and fibrin causing luminal narrowing. This causes shear stress that injures passing RBCs.

questions.text: A HIV positive patient presented to OPD with painless blurring of vision. Fundoscopy  findings shown below. What is the management of this condition?

questions.text: A young woman presents with burning micturition and fever for the past two days. Gram stain of the urine sample was performed which revealed pink organisms. It was also cultured on MacConkey's agar which can be seen below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism in this patient with features of urinary tract infection, gram-negative organism (pink color in gram staining), and lactose fermenting (pink) colonies in MacConkey's agar is Escherichia coli. 

Urinary tract infection (UTI) can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. Symptomatic UTI is characterized by burning micturition, increased frequency of micturition, urgency, pelvic discomfort, and pain. If pyelonephritis is present, there will also be flank pain. In asymptomatic patients, bacteriuria is present and in women, if untreated can lead to complications during pregnancy. 

UTI can be caused by a variety of organisms. Since the question stem describes a gram-negative (pink gram staining organism) and lactose fermenting (pink colonies on MacConkey agar), the causative organism is likely E. coli.

E. coli grows well on ordinary media, is hemolytic on blood agar, demonstrates uniform turbidity with a heavy deposit in broth, and ferments glucose, lactose, mannitol, and maltose. It has several virulence factors:

  • Surface antigens:
    • Colonization factor antigens
    • Lipopolysaccharide O antigen
    • P fimbria
  • Toxins:
    • Hemolysins
    • Cytotoxic necrotizing factor-1
    • Heat-labile toxin
    • Heat-stable toxin
    • Shiga-like toxin (E.coli verocytotoxin or verotoxin )

Lower UTIs caused by E. coli are generally caused by the same serotype present in the gut of the patient due to ascending infection. Upper UTIs caused by E. coli are generally due to hematogenous spread. 

It is diagnosed by demonstrating 'significant bacteriuria' which is 100,000 and more bacteria. This is because the urine can be contaminated with E. coli during sample collection so a significant presence of the organism has to be present for diagnosis. 

Other options: 

Option B - Proteus mirabilis is a non-lactose fermenting bacteria. Although it is a normal commensal of the intestine, it is not a coliform bacteria. It is a gram-negative, encapsulated, pleomorphic, motile rod. 

Option C - Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus that is actively motile, encapsulated, with a mucoid slime layer. It forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

The following image shows non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar:

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus is a lactose fermenter. However, it is a gram-positive organism. It produces characteristic golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A young woman reported palpitations, dizziness, and sweating while getting ready for an office seminar. She recalls having experienced similar episodes in the past. She also reports having feelings of impending doom during these episodes. There is no history of medical illness or substance abuse. Which of the following is not useful in the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic disorder. Flumazenil is not useful in the treatment of this condition and may even act as a panic-inducing substance (panicogen).

Panic disorder refers to an acute intense attack of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Such attacks may not only occur in response to a fearful situation, or phobic objects, or in response to obsession or separation as in other anxiety disorders.

There is a dysfunction in major neurotransmitter systems like norepinephrine, serotonin, and GABA. Panic-inducing substances or panicogens may induce such attacks and include substances like 5-35% carbon dioxide, sodium lactate, bicarbonate, yohimbine (α blocker), flumazenil (GABA antagonist), cholecystokinin and caffeine.

This disorder is characterised by the presence of an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes. During the episode, the person may experience symptoms like palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, shortness of breath, nausea, dizziness, chest pain or discomfort or fear of dying. The patient also might feel like losing control, having a heart attack, or going crazy. 

It is not attributable to any drug abuse, medication, medical condition or mental disorder.

Treatment of this condition can be done by cognitive behavioural therapy and drugs like benzodiazepines (alprazolam, lorazepam), selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (paroxetine), tricyclic antidepressants and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Panic disorder

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

1.Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:

  • Palpitation
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Shortness of breath of smothering sensation
  • Choking sensation
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Chills or heat sensation
  • Paraesthesia’s
  • Derealisation or depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control or “going crazy”
  • Fear of dying  

 2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

  • Immediate: benzodiazepines 
  • Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

questions.text:
A toddler presents with persistent diarrhea for three weeks. Stool culture reveals EAEC as the causative agent. What is the typical appearance of EAEC on the HEp-2 cell line?

EAEC - Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli
questions.solution:
When the Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAEC) strain is cultured on the HEp-2 cell line, it shows a characteristic appearance called stacked brick formation.  This appearance is caused by the aggregative nature of the bacteria.

EAEC is associated with acute, prolonged, and persistent pediatric diarrhea most prominently in children < 2 year old and in malnourished children. EAEC is the 2nd most common cause of traveler's diarrhea after ETEC.

HEp-2 is a continuous cell line derived from human cancers that can be cultivated indefinitely. HEp-2  and other standard cell lines like HeLa and KB have been used in labs worldwide. These cells can be maintained through subcultivation or stored at -70°C.

Other Options:

Option A - Syncytium formation is seen in Respiratory syncytial virus when grown on HEp-2 cells.

Option B - Grape-like cluster formation is seen in Adenovirus when grown on HEp-2 cells.

Option D - Cytoplasmic vacuolation is seen in Simian virus 40 when grown on HEp-2 cells.

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary tuberculosis comes for a follow-up. While presenting the history, you explain to the medical students that this is a case of chronic inflammation where macrophages predominate. Which of the following statements is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation?

choices.text: Activation of this pathway is induced by endotoxins
Th1 CD4+T lymphocytes are essential for the activation of this pathway
Interferon-gamma is the primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway
Main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation

questions.solution:
The statement main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation.

Macrophages are the predominant cells involved in chronic inflammation. These cells are derived from precursors in the embryonic yolk sac and fetal liver in prenatal life and from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow in postnatal life.

The principal functions of macrophages in chronic inflammation are as follows:

  • Microbicidal activity by secretion of cytokines
  • Continuation of the inflammatory response
  • Initiation of tissue repair and end inflammatory response
  • Sending and responding to signals from T lymphocytes that are essential for cell-mediated defense mechanisms

The abovementioned functions of macrophages are carried out once they are activated by two principal pathways:

  • Classical macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M1 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by microbial endotoxins and other products that activate toll-like receptors (TLRs).
    • The primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway is interferon-gamma.
    • Microbicidal actions that are mediated by the release of nitric oxide, reactive oxygen species, and lysosomal enzymes are the primary function of M1 macrophages.
    • Release of IL-1, IL-12, and IL-23 by M1 macrophages is involved in promoting the inflammatory response.
  • Alternate macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M2 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by IL-4 and IL-13 produced by T-lymphocytes.
    • Tissue repair is the primary function mediated by growth factors and transforming growth factors-β (TGF-β).
    • Cessation of inflammation is another important function mediated by IL-10, TGF-β. 

Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.

TH1 cells - activate macrophages by the classical pathway by secreting IFN­γ.

TH2 cells - recruit and activate eosinophils and are responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation by secreting IL­4, IL­5, and IL­13.

TH17 cells - secrete IL­17 and other cytokines, which are responsible for neutrophils and monocyte recruitment.

questions.text: During an abdominal surgery, a surgeon accidentally ligates the structure marked in the image. What could be the expected outcome for this patient?
questions.solution:
The vessel marked in the image is the 'right gonadal artery/ right testicular artery' and it is identified by its origin from the abdominal aorta just below the left renal vein. It supplies the right testis and epididymis, hence the ligation of the testicular artery can result in testicular ischaemia which is the most appropriate answer among the given options.

The testicular artery provides blood to the:

  • Upper and middle sections of the proximal ureter.
  • Within the inguinal canal, it divides into internal testicular arteries which supply blood to different parts of the epididymis.
  • Near the testis, these branches enter the tunica albuginea. They mainly spread across the front, middle, and side areas of the lower part of the testis.     

The gonadal arteries, whether ovarian or testicular, are two elongated, thin vessels originating from the aorta slightly below the renal arteries. Each travels inferolaterally beneath the posterior parietal peritoneum that covers the psoas major, providing blood to the corresponding gonad. As an anatomical variant one or both gonadal arteries may potentially branch from a renal artery or exist as duplicates.

Other options:

Option A: Ligating the inferior mesenteric artery during aortic surgery can raise the risk of ischaemic colitis. Splenic flexure is the most commonly affected part of the colon while other parts of the colon are also involved. However most cases of colonic ischemia result from decreased blood flow or blockage in small blood vessels due to vascular disease or diabetes.

Option C: Compression of the renal vein by nearby structures, such as the superior mesenteric artery, can lead to increased pressure in the testicular veins, potentially causing varicocele.

Option D: The ureters arise from the renal pelvis and run alongside the psoas major muscle in the abdomen and enter pelvis . Understanding the anatomical relationship of the ureters is crucial for surgical procedures involving the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.

    • Gonadal artery - L2

    • Lumbar artery (four pairs) - L1 to L4
    • Median sacral artery - L4

questions.text: Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are called:
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are Brenner tumors or transitional cell tumors.

Transitional cell tumors are a rare type of ovarian epithelial tumor. They contain neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium and are usually benign. They are often detected incidentally and even when large they do not produce any symptoms.

Microscopy features include fibrous stroma, with sharply demarcated nests of urothelial cells, often with mucinous glands in their center, called Walthard cell rests, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option B- Krukenberg tumor is a bilateral metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site in the gastrointestinal tract. Microscopically, it is characterized by the appearance of mucin-secreting signet-ring cells in the tissue of the ovary.

Option C- Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor that commonly produces masculinization or defeminization. These tumors showed a range of  differentiation:

 - Well-differentiated tumors show tubules composed of Sertoli cells or Leydig cells interspersed with stroma
 - Intermediate forms show immature tubules with large eosinophilic Leydig cell
 - Poorly differentiated show sarcomatous pattern

Option D- Hilus cell tumors or pure Leydig cell tumors are also sex cord-stromal tumors. They are rare and unilateral tumors. Large lipid-laden Leydig cells with distinct borders and characteristic rod-shaped cytoplasmic structures called Reinke crystalloids are present in these tumors. Females with hilus cell tumors usually have features of masculinization.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male patient, diagnosed with HIV, presents with complaints of 4 weeks of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. CMV colitis is suspected. Which is the diagnostic investigation of choice?

HIV - Human Immunodeficiency Virus

CMV - Cytomegalovirus
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of CMV colitis can be established by colonoscopy and biopsy. Multiple mucosal ulcerations are seen at colonoscopy, and biopsies reveal characteristic intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis should be considered in AIDS patients with CD4+ lymphocyte count <50/μL, fevers, and diarrhea. It presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and anorexia. Diarrhea is usually non-bloody. 

The initial evaluation of a patient with HIV infection and diarrhea should include a set of stool examinations, including culture, examination for ova and parasites, and examination for Clostridium difficile toxin. Approximately 50% of the time this workup will demonstrate infection with pathogenic bacteria, mycobacteria, or protozoa. If the initial stool examinations are negative, additional evaluation, including upper and/or lower endoscopy with biopsy, will yield a diagnosis of microsporidial or mycobacterial infection of the small intestine ~30% of the time. In patients for whom this diagnostic evaluation is nonrevealing, a presumptive diagnosis of HIV enteropathy can be made if the diarrhea has persisted for >1 month. An algorithm for the evaluation of diarrhea in patients with HIV infection is given below :

CMV colitis is treated with either valganciclovir/ganciclovir or foscarnet for 3–6 weeks. Relapses are common, and maintenance therapy is typically necessary in patients whose HIV infection is poorly controlled. Patients with CMV disease of the GI tract should be carefully monitored for evidence of CMV retinitis.

questions.text: A 40-year old businessman presented with a history of sleeping attacks in between his business meetings. He complained of episodes where he is unable to move while trying to wake up in the morning and that he feels a loss of strength and falls to the ground whenever he is stressed. Which of the following changes in neurotransmitters is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy. It is characterised by decreased levels of orexin/hypocretin in the lateral hypothlamus.

Narcolepsy is the classical example of sleepiness caused due to CNS dysfunction of sleep mechanisms, mainly, a genetically triggered hypocretin deficit and dysfunction.

Orexins (Previously known as hypocretins) are neuropeptides synthesized by hypothalamic neurons and involved in regulation of food intake and energy expenditure and also in sleep regulation.

Orexinergic neurons project from the hypothalamus to a number of monoaminergic centers including the locus coeruleus, raphe nuclei, and ventral tegmentum.

Functions:

  • Regulation of sleep: 
    • Hypothalamus – key regulating centre
    • GABAergic neurons of the ventrolateral preoptic area (VLPO) - Sleep-promoting
    • Orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus - Wakefulness-promoting
  • Regulation of food intake and energy expenditure. Orexin production can increase food craving

Levels of hypocretin receptor-I are undetectable in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of individuals who are HLA­ DQB 1*0602-positive (consistent with cataplexy-associated narcolepsy).

The classic form of narcolepsy (narcolepsy with cataplexy) is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms:

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

Symptoms commonly appear in the second decade of life. Strong emotions (such as laughter and anger) usually act as the trigger for cataplexy.

Pharmacotherapy remains the treatment of choice. Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, is used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and to improve psychomotor performance in narcolepsy. Besides this, imipramine and fluoxetine are also found effective in eliminating cataplexy.

questions.text: What is the optimal treatment approach for diabetes caused by a mutation in the glucokinase gene?
questions.solution:
Diabetes caused by mutation in glucokinase enzyme is suggestive of maturity-onset diabetes of young type 2, which is best managed with dietary modification alone.

Maturity onset diabetes of young type 2 (MODY 2) is a monogenic disorder caused by a mutation in the glucokinase gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. There is an early onset of hyperglycemia (<25 years). Patients are typically not obese.

Glucokinase catalyzes the formation of glucose-6-phosphate from glucose, an important reaction for glucose sensing by the beta cells and for glucose utilization by the liver. As a result of glucokinase mutations, higher glucose levels are required to elicit insulin secretory responses, thus altering the set point for insulin secretion. Hence, patients tend to have elevated fasting blood glucose but do not usually develop postprandial hyperglycemia as they have sufficient insulin secretion in response to elevated glucose.

MODY 2 is non-ketotic, and patients do not have pancreatic autoantibodies. The hyperglycemia in these patients is often stable and mild and is therefore not associated with the vascular complications common in other types of diabetes. Because of the pathology involved in the disease, MODY2 does not respond to oral hypoglycemic agents and does not require treatment. There is no role of insulin therapy either as there is no significant therapeutic outcome. Consequently, such patients can usually be managed with lifestyle modifications and diet alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is a vascular phenomenon of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Janeway lesions are due to a vascular phenomenon in infective endocarditis.

Janeway lesions are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles. They are vascular lesions caused due to deposition of septic emboli in the dermis. 

Other vascular manifestations of  include:

  • Septic pulmonary infarcts
  • Mycotic aneurysm
  • Splinter hemorrhages
  • Conjunctival hemorrhages

 

Immunological presentations of infective endocarditis include:

  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Roth spots
  • Positive rheumatoid factor
  • Osler's node - these are small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Choose the cardiac event that corresponds to the phase of isovolumetric contraction.
questions.solution:
Isovolumetric contraction corresponds best with "c" wave of JVP. 

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

questions.text: A test is done to check the immediate sign of death where fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base. What is the name of this test?
questions.solution:
Fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base is a feature of Magnus’s test (Ligature test). It is one of the tests used to confirm the cessation of circulation.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes.

Other tests:

  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test)—fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base.
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test)—Failure to show redness in the web space between the fingers on transillumination from behind.
  • Icard’s test — fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration.
  • Fingernail test — no blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release.

Tests for confirming cessation of breathing:

No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes, confirms cessation of breathing.

 Other tests:

  • Feather test – No movement of a feather held in front of the nose.
  • Mirror test – A mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture of breath.
  • Winslow’s test – No movement of the surface of the water in a bowl kept on the chest.

questions.text:
Identify the true statement regarding the regulation of the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis.

ATP - Adenosine triphosphate

GMP - Guanosine monophosphate
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis is phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP) glutamyl amidotransferase; it is inhibited by GMP which is one of the end products of the pathway & activated by the concentration of glutamine.

De novo purine synthesis involves the synthesis of purines from amphibolic intermediates. The first step of this reaction involves the transfer of two phosphoryl groups from ATP to ribose-5-phosphate form 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP), catalyzed by the enzyme PRPP synthase. PRPP is then converted to 5-phosphoribosylamine by the enzyme PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase, in the presence of glutamine and H2O; this undergoes a series of changes to form inosine monophosphate (IMP).

The IMP formed can then be used for the synthesis of both AMP and GMP by different pathways. Subsequently, one ATP is used for the conversion of AMP to ADP and GMP to GDP; this is followed by the synthesis of GTP from GDP using another phosphoryl group from ATP, while ADP can be converted to ATP by oxidative phosphorylation.

The rate of the reaction is determined by the intracellular concentration of PRPP, which in turn depends on the rate of PRPP synthesis and utilization. The rate of PRPP synthesis depends on the availability of ribose-5-phosphate and on the activity of PRPP synthase, an enzyme whose activity is feedback inhibited by AMP, ADP, GMP, and GDP. Additionally, the enzyme PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase is inhibited by AMP and GMP, the end products of the pathway.

The other compounds that block purine biosynthesis include azaserine, 6-mercaptopurine, methotrexate and mycophenolic acid.

Out of the options, Syrup nevirapine would started if the mother is known HIV positive and viral load less than 1000copies/mL.

All infants born to HIV-positive mothers test positive for HIV antibodies due to passive transfer from the infected mother. Babies who remain uninfected may become seroconverters after losing maternal antibodies around 6-12 months of age.

Nevirapine PLUS twice-daily zidovudine for six weeks, followed by an additional six weeks of the same combination regimen or nevirapine alone is recommended for High risk infants with mothers who are:

  • HIV positive not on ART
  • Mother diagnosed with HIV 72 hours after delivery.
  • On ART with viral load > 1000 copies/mL
  • With unknown viral load, hasn't been on ART for >4 consecutive weeks.

Daily nevirapine for six weeks is recommended for low risk infants with mothers who are:

  • On ART with viral load < 1000 copies/mL
  • With unknown viral load, has been on ART for >4 consecutive weeks

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text:
A biochemist is interested in accurately measuring GFR in a patient. He uses a substance that is freely filtered by the glomerulus and neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the renal tubules. The substance used to measure GFR is a polysaccharide of which of the following?

GFR: Glomerular Filtration Rate
questions.solution:
The substance used by the biochemist to accurately measure GFR which is neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules is most likely inulin. It is a polysaccharide of fructose.

Inulin is composed of D-fructose units with repeating beta-1,2 linkages. It is of plant origin and is found in tubers and roots of dahlias, artichokes, and dandelions. Clearance of inulin can be used for the measurement of GFR as it is readily soluble in water, freely filtered, neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules, nontoxic and is not metabolized by the body.

Other options: 

Option A: Important polysaccharides composed of glucose include starch, glycogen, and cellulose.

Option B: Galactose combines with glucose to form lactose. It is also a component of glycoproteins in nerve tissue.

Option C: Sucrose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child diagnosed with bronchial asthma requires bronchodilator therapy. Which of the following device will you prescribe for this child, to avoid oropharyngeal adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The device in image 3 is a spacer device that can be prescribed to decrease the incidence of propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug depositing in the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drugs inhaled into the lower airways. Thus, a less amount of the drug gets swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract and limits local side effects. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.


The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDI) - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and can deliver 50–200 doses of a drug.

Image 1 in the question stem shows a pressurized metered-dose inhaler.


Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children below 7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 

Image 2 in the question stem shows a dry powder inhaler.


Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -

  • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
  • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

Image 4 in the question stem shows a nebulizer.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

It receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve with a root value of C6, C7, and C8.

It is an extensor of the elbow. It receives its vascular supply from branches of the posterior interosseous recurrent artery.

questions.text: While examining a 2-year-old child with peripheral edema, you notice alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal-pigmented areas on the hair strands. Which condition is this clinical finding typically associated with?
questions.solution:
Peripheral edema and alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand, i.e. the flag sign are typically associated with kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by pitting peripheral edema and apathy. It usually affects infants and children, most often around the age of weaning till the age of 4. Children are miserable, often refuse to eat with marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

Children with kwashiorkor have moon-shaped faces. Peripheral edema and abdominal distension due to hepatomegaly are consistent features. Skin changes of increased pigmentation in some sites along with desquamation results in 'flaky paint' or 'crazy pavement' dermatoses.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish. Alternating bands of hypopigmented and pigmented hair may be seen, known as the flag sign due to growth spurts. These growth spurts are not seen in a child with Marasmus. 


Other options:

Option A: Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition that occurs usually in children < 1 year due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears very thin, having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. Due to its aged and wrinkled appearance, the loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face'. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

The hair and nails often grow slowly and show brittleness. The hair is easily pluckable and areas of alopecia may be seen but not flag sign as there is no growth spurts in a child with marasmus. Lanugo hair may be observed on the face and neck. 


Option B: Pellagra is caused to niacin deficiency and presents as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis of pellagra is an intermittent, painful, or pruritic erythema and edema in sun-exposed areas. It gradually becomes a sharply marginated, hyperpigmented keratotic plaque. It commonly affects the dorsum of the hands. It can be associated with protein-energy malnutrition but not associated with any hair changes.


Option C: Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. It presents after weaning with diarrhea, alopecia, and a cutaneous eruption in the periorificial and acral areas. Children often have symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusted edges. It is associated with nutritional alopecia like marasmus and kwashiorkor but flag sign is not seen.
