questions.text: Graph A displays a pressure-volume loop of a fetal lung in utero. Following birth, the pressure-volume loop transforms into Graph B. What process is crucial for this change to take place in the alveoli?

choices.text: Increased collapsing pressure and decreased compliance
Increased surface tension and reduced radius
Decreased compliance  and decreased collapsing pressure
Decreased surface tension and increased compliance

questions.solution:
Graph A depicts the plot from a liquid-ventilated lung and graph B depicts a gas-ventilated lung. The transition in the lung from Graph A to Graph B is due to decreased surface tension and increased compliance.

Difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed as hysteresis and mainly depends upon the production of surfactant.During Fetal life, the lung remains collapsed and filled with fluid. At birth, an increase in surfactant production with multiple inspiratory efforts lowers surface tension, leading to enhanced lung compliance. This is following the Laplace law.

As per the Laplace law,

where,

P = Collapsing pressure on alveolus (dynes/cm2) or Pressure required to keep alveoli open

T = Surface tension (dynes/cm)

r = Radius of the alveolus (cm)

Collapsing pressure is inversely related to radius i.e., a large alveolus (one with a large radius) will have a low collapsing pressure and therefore will require only minimal pressure to keep it open. On the other hand, a small alveolus (one with a small radius) will have a high collapsing pressure and require more pressure to keep it open.

Therefore, To shift from graph A to B, the following changes are required in the alveoli:

  • Decrease in collapsing pressure.
  • Increase in compliance.
  • Increase in radius.
  • Decrease in surface tension.

By reducing surface tension, surfactant reduces the collapsing pressure for a given radius. The given diagram shows how surfactant reduces surface tension inside the alveoli:

Clinical correlation- Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Deficiency of surfactant leads to respiratory distress syndrome. This is common in preterm infants. In fetal development, pulmonary epithelial cells secrete Cl– along with fluid. However, at birth, these cells transition to absorbing Na+ through the epithelial Na+ channels (ENaCs), leading to fluid absorption along with Na+. Prolonged immaturity of the ENaCs is implicated in the pulmonary abnormalities observed in IRDS.

Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:

  • Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio, i.e. L/S ratio of ≥2 is considered normal.
  • Shake test/ Bubble test/ Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has an absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF, which is involved in the clearance of surfactant
     

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

Related Pearl: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

  • SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.
  • SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with an acute-onset neck spasm. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he had been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage, the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Acute dystonia usually presents within hours or days of starting treatment with antipsychotic drugs. There is a higher risk among patients between the ages of 10–19. It occurs due to acute dopamine receptor antagonism.  It presents with spasms of the head and neck muscles and the tongue. The severest form includes an oculogyric crisis with extraocular muscle involvement.

Treatment is with anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

Option A: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements, and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.

Option C: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs weeks to months after starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, extreme muscle rigidity, stupor, dystonia, tachycardia, and unstable blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine. The antipsychotic drug responsible should be immediately stopped.

Option D: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by choreiform movements which are quick, repetitive, involuntary movements, along with slower twisting athetotic movements. It occurs months or years after initiation of the treatment and is more frequent in the elderly.

questions.text: A young man presented with the features of pancreatitis. Subsequent investigations showed the pancreatic anatomy to be as depicted in the image below. What is the likely embryological defect in this case?

choices.text: Failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud
Failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds
Failure of the complete rotation of the dorsal pancreatic bud
Hypoplasia of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds

questions.solution:
The given image shows pancreas divisum, which occurs due to the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.

During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal duct usually persists as an accessory duct.

In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds, leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum or pancreas divisum. Pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla.

Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, pancreas divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis.

Option A - Failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to annular pancreas.

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view that is not possible with FAST but is possible with eFAST?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography, used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. The following regions are scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view (also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: An ultrasound image of the lung would show a seashore sign in case of a _____.
questions.solution:
An ultrasound image of the lung would show a seashore sign in case of a normal lung.

On M-mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

The M-mode image in the pneumothorax demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign, indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign, and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets presents with normal levels of serum calcium.

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets has X-linked dominant inheritance. There is a mutation in PHEX gene, which leads to elevated FGF23. FGF23 inhibits renal tubular phosphate absorption, thus leading to its increased excretion.

Clinical features include bony deformities in children. They particularly develop genu valgum or genu varum when they begin to walk. Adults develop heterotrophic bone formation around large joints and ligaments of the spinal canal. This leads to enthesopathies and neurological symptoms.

Laboratory findings include low serum phosphorus level, elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level, but normal serum levels of PTH and calcium.

Treatment includes a combination of phosphorus and calcitriol. The response is monitored by checking the levels of alkaline phosphatase, which tend to normalize on treatment. The balance between phosphorus and calcitriol is very important. Excess phosphorus supplementation will decrease calcium absorption from the intestine, leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism and thus worsening bone lesions. Excess calcitriol on the other hand can cause hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 18-year-old daughter for a psychiatric evaluation as she has no friends and is overly fascinated by magical thoughts.  She also believes she has superpowers. What is the most likely type of personality disorder she has?
questions.solution:
The most likely personality disorder based on the clinical features is schizotypal personality disorder.

Inability to maintain close relationships, magical thinking, and a belief that they possess superpowers are suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behavior. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition. Pscytherapy is the first line treatment for pateints for schizotypal personality disorder.

Personality disorders are divided into three clusters:

  • Cluster A: Schizotypal, schizoid, and paranoid
  • Cluster B: Narcissistic, borderline, antisocial, and histrionic
  • Cluster C: Obsessive-compulsive, dependent, and avoidant

Other options:

Option A: Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection and leads a socially withdrawn life but a strong desire for relationships.

Option B: Narcissistic personality disorder is marked by a heightened sense of self-importance. Individuals with this personality disorder display a lack of empathy and grandiose feelings. This is to mask their fragile self-esteem and vulnerability.

Option C- Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a tendency for social withdrawal, isolation, and introversion. They tend to take up jobs that require minimal interpersonal interaction. They are emotionally detached, aloof, and avoid eye contact.

questions.text: As a Casualty medical officer on duty during a mass casualty, which tag would you use for a patient with a less urgent condition needing admission for monitoring, evaluation, and treatment?
questions.solution:

 The other two colours under the three-tier based ATP are:

  • Red-triaged patients are those who need immediate life-saving interventions and have the presence of any altered physiological parameters, any time-sensitive conditions or conditions with increased urgency 
  • Green-triaged patients are given minor treatment and discharged.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and restricted ocular movements that have gotten progressively worse over a period of time. There is no exacerbation or remission. Initially, the upgaze was involved with subsequent lateral gaze involvement. The patient does not complain of diplopia and the pupils are not involved. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).

CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

Isolated CPEO usually presents with bilateral ptosis as the first sign. It may be asymmetrical. It usually begins in young adulthood and is typically characterized by a progressive course without remission or exacerbation. At first, only the upgaze is involved, and later, the lateral gaze is also affected. Since the loss of eye movement is symmetrical, diplopia is rare. Pupils are not involved.

Electromyography shows myotonic and myopathic potentials and serum creatine kinase is elevated.

Treatment involves exercise and the prevention of contractures. A minority of patients with diplopia may benefit from surgery.

Other options:

Options A and D- In cranial nerve palsies, there would be associated diplopia.

Option C- In ocular myasthenia gravis, diplopia is very commonly seen.

questions.text: A male baby was brought to the pediatrician in the 5th week of life with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign on ultrasound is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hence the ABG which shows a pH: 7.48, pCO2: 47, HCO3: 30 is the answer.

A pH >7.40, with increased HCO3, and increased pCO2 indicate metabolic alkalosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach
  • Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: An elderly male presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, distension and constipation. X-ray of the abdomen reveals a 'coffee-bean ' sign. He is set to undergo Paul -Mikulicz procedure. Which of the following best describes the procedure?

choices.text: Proctocolectomy with ileal pouch anal anastomosis
Proximal and distal colons simultaneously brought out as colostomies
Proximal colon brought out as a colostomy , and distal colon  retained in abdomen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with the X-ray finding, suggests that the patient has sigmoid volvulus. Paul Mikulicz procedure is done in emergencies if there is suspicion of impending gangrene, where the proximal and distal colons are simultaneously brought out as colostomies.

Sigmoid volvulus is a condition where the sigmoid colon twists around its blood supply at the base of the mesentery. It presents with symptoms of large bowel obstruction. Patients tend to be elderly and institutionalized. Abdominal distension is an early and progressive sign. Constipation is absolute. X-ray of the abdomen shows a “bent inner tube” or “coffee bean” sign, where the apex of the dilated colon points into the right upper quadrant.

Unless there are obvious signs of gangrene or peritonitis, the initial management of sigmoid volvulus endoscopic detorsion (option A) with a flexible or rigid sigmoidoscopy and insertion of a flatus tube. Although this successfully reduces sigmoid volvulus in most patients, the risk of recurrence is high (up to 40%). For this reason, an elective sigmoid colectomy should be performed after the patient has been stabilized and undergone adequate bowel preparation.

In an emergency with evidence of necrosis, it may be wise to ligate the mesenteric vessels before untwisting the volvulus to theoretically avoid the systemic release of ischaemic toxins. It may also be prudent to avoid anastomosis.  In this situation, the following procedures are considered:

  • Paul-Mikulicz procedure - after sigmoidectomy, the proximal and distal colons are brought out simultaneously as a double-barrelled colostomy.
  • Hartmann procedure - after resecting the sigmoid colon, the proximal colon is brought out as an end colostomy, while the distal colon is retained as a stump in the abdomen(option D).

A second-stage colorectal anastomosis can be planned when the patient is fit.

Other options : 

Option B - Proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is a procedure employed in inflammatory bowel diseases and familial adenomatous polyposis, where gastrointestinal continuity is desired. After the excision of the colon and rectum, a substitute rectum is made from the joined folds of ileum to form an expanded pouch of small intestine. The pouch is then joined directly to the anus, at the level of the dentate line.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. The image shows a CT scan of the skull. Biochemical tests show raised alkaline phosphatase and normal serum calcium. The most likely diagnosis is?

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given image shows Tam o'Shanter sign and clinical findings suggest Paget's disease of bone or osteitis deformans.

Paget's disease is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localized sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal and the bone is unusually brittle. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase is seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal

The radiological signs seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected.
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

Image shows cotton wool appearance of skull seen in Paget's disease.

Tam o'Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph resembling the Scottish Tam o'Shanter hat.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is caused due to increased parathyroid hormone. It causes osteoclastic resorption of bone leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, depression. Sub-periosteal resorption of the phalanges is a diagnostic feature of hyperparathyroidism. The x-ray skull shows a salt pepper appearance showing a well-marked stippling, but the opaque areas are small pinhead size.

Image shows salt and pepper appearance seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Osteopetrosis occurs due to a defect in the genes that control the osteoclastic activity and hence usually presents much earlier in life. Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. The bones appear sclerotic and the skull base is uniformly radiodense. Radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the ‘rugger-jersey’ sign. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity
 

An X-ray image showing dense bones seen in osteopetrosis is shown below.

Option D: Osteomyelitis can occur in the frontal bone is associated with forehead swelling and redness. It usually results from acute frontal sinusitis but can also occur as sequelae of trauma or surgery. Pus can be formed under the periosteum as soft boggy swelling called pott's puffy tumor. ESR and CRP are elevated with leukocytosis, serum calcium and ALP are usually unchanged. X-ray is done initially but a CT scan clinches the diagnosis. Radionuclide scanning, MRI are other radiological investigations that are used.

Image shows MRI, T1, sagittal, gadolinium contrast showing pott's puffy tumor, spreading towards patients' brain.

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

  • Pain at the site before the fracture
  • Multiple recent fractures

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with a history of frequent infections, fatigue, headaches and blurring of vision. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests show normocytic normochromic anemia and a positive Coombs test, with serum electrophoresis revealing a sharp spike of monoclonal IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has classic symptoms due to hyperviscosity, like headache and blurring of vision, and has a spike of monoclonal IgM. The most likely diagnosis is Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that results in increased proliferation of memory B cells. These cells produce large amounts of IgM, leading to the classic hyperviscosity syndrome. 

Patients present with anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hyperviscosity, or peripheral neuropathy. Most commonly, they present with fatigue, weakness, and oozing of blood from the nasal or oral cavity. 

Haematological examination reveals Coombs’ positive test and rouleaux formation. This condition also has a greater incidence of normocytic normochromic anaemia.

The hyperviscosity state can be treated by plasmapheresis. However, most patients do not require therapy unless they are symptomatic (anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.) It can be treated with ibrutinib, which targets the activated BTK mutation. Rituximab with cyclophosphamide can also be used. 

Option A - Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a condition that results in the proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is characterised by night sweats, fever, fatigue, and painless supraclavicular and axillary lymphadenopathy. There are no hyperviscosity symptoms or hepatosplenomegaly. 

Option B - Multiple myeloma and Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia are similar in course as they are both plasma cell disorders. However, there are several key differences between the two. Lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure, which are more suggestive of myeloma, are not seen in this patient. Also, multiple myeloma has a spike of IgG in the majority of the cases.

Option D - Amyloidosis involves the extracellular deposition of fibrillary proteins. There is usually multiorgan involvement, most commonly leading to renal, splenic, and cardiac disease. The IgM spike that is present in this patient would not be seen in amyloidosis.

questions.text: X is a drug that follows first-order kinetics. A 40 mg intravenous dose results in a plasma concentration of 2mg/L. What is the volume of distribution of this drug?
questions.solution:
Based on the parameters given, the volume of the distribution of the drug is 20 litres.

The volume of distribution, given by the following formula is used to calculate it.

Volume of distribution of drug (Vd) = Amount of drug administered in the body/ plasma concentration observed 

Here, the amount of drug administered to this patient is 40mg intravenously and the plasma concentration observed is 2 mg/litre. Substituting the values in the formula,

Vd=40/2=20 L

questions.text: All of the following are techniques that you can use for delivery of the head in breech presentation, except for ___.
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor, not in breech presentation.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region) while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: An 11-year-old child underwent surgery for recurrent intussusception. A segment of intestine had to be removed and the subsequent histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following features is likely seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of intussusception and histopathology image characterized by an arborizing network of smooth muscle fibers continuous with the muscularis mucosa that supports the glandular epithelium of the polyp are suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. The morphology of Peutz-Jeghers polyps can overlap with that of sporadic hamartomatous polyps, the presence of multiple polyps in the small intestine, mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, and a positive family history are critical to the diagnosis.

Intussusception is commonly associated with side effects of rotavirus vaccine and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple intestinal hamartomatous polyps  and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the STK11 gene are present in approximately half of individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

The polyps are more common in the small intestine > colon > stomach.  This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception
  • There is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Other options:

Option B: Facial trichilemmomas which is a hamartoma of hair follicles seen in Cowden syndrome 

Option D: Pigmented ocular fundus is seen in Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) presents with and is usually associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. What is the most common transmission mode of this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and hysterosalpingogram finding of "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It mostly spreads via hematogenous route.

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

The fallopian tubes are the most common site to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. 

Investigations:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) - If genital tuberculosis is suspected, HSG should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • The jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube

3. The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. 

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

Other options:

Option A: Ascending infection -  Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, cause ascending infection through the urethra and cervix

Option C: Sexually transmitted infection - Syphilis, Chancroid, Chlamydia, Gonorrhoea, and Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) are examples of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Genital TB is not a STD. 

Option D: Direct invasion - Treponema pallidum, Haemophilus ducreyi, and Herpes simplex virus spread by invading the skin and the mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a testicular swelling was operated upon and the tumor was removed. HPE of the tumor is as given below. All are true regarding the given condition except:

choices.text: Metastasis is mainly through the lymphatics
Percutaneous testicular biopsy is ideal for confirmation
The tumor is removed by high inguinal orchidectomy

questions.solution:
The histopathology is diagnostic of testicular seminoma. The biopsy increases the risk of the spread of the cancer cells to the scrotum. Therefore, a biopsy should not be done on the suspected testicular tumors. Inguinal orchiectomy is done in such cases.

The histopathological examination of seminoma shows sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor. It is common in men between 20-40 years of age.

The patients usually present with a painless testicular lump. If a testicular tumor is suspected, blood samples are taken from the patient for the evaluation of the tumor markers (hCG, LDH, and AFP), and the diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound scanning of the testis. A high inguinal orchidectomy is performed.

Further treatment of seminoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Stage I tumors, whose levels of tumor markers decline after orchidectomy may not require further treatment. Stage II-IV tumors require radiotherapy and chemotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used are bleomycin, etoposide, and platin based agents (BEP).

questions.text: A culture report of pus, obtained from the surgical site of a post-op patient, reveals bacterial growth susceptible to tigecycline. At what site in the bacterial cell does it exert its antimicrobial effect?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline acts at site 4 - 30S subunit of ribosomes.

Tigecycline is a member of a new class of synthetic tetracycline analogs called glycyl-cyclines and is a derivative of minocycline. It has a broad spectrum of activity and is active against most bacteria that have developed resistance to the classical tetracyclines. 

The mechanism of action is similar to that of tetracyclines, i.e. inhibiting protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosomes and preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the acceptor (A) site of the mRNA-ribosome complex.

Tigecycline is active against : 

  • Most Gram-positive and Gram-negative cocci and anaerobes (including tetracycline-resistant strains of Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, MRSA, VRSA, VRE)
  • Most Enterobacteriaceae, Acinetobacter, Rickettsia, Chlamydia

Pseudomonas and Proteus are inherently nonresponsive to tigecycline.

The lack of cross-resistance with tetracyclines is mainly because the tetracycline efflux pumps have a low affinity for tigecycline.

Tigecycline is poorly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract; the only route of administration is by slow i.v. infusion. It is eliminated mainly in the bile and dose adjustment is not needed in renal insufficiency. The duration of action is long, with elimination t1/2 of 37-67 hours.

Tigecycline is approved for the treatment of : 

  • Serious and hospitalized patients with community-acquired pneumonia
  • Complicated skin and skin structure infections (but not diabetic foot)
  • Complicated intraabdominal infections caused by Enterococci, anaerobes and Enterobacteriaceae

It is not recommended for hospital-acquired/ventilator-associated chest infections. It is also not suitable for urinary tract infection, because only low concentrations are attained in urine.

Other options:

Option A - Antibiotics acting on the cell wall are beta-lactams( penicillins, cephalosporins, monobactams, carbapenems) and glycopeptides (vancomycin, teicoplanin).

Option B - DNA gyrase is inhibited by fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin).

Option C - Drugs acting on the 50S subunit of ribosomes are macrolides(erythromycin, azithromycin), lincosamide (clindamycin), streptogramins (quinupristin-dalfopristin), oxazolidinones (linezolid) and chloramphenicol.

  • Another class of antibiotics acting on the 30S ribosomal subunit is aminoglycosides.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman complains of frequent headaches. On ophthalmic examination, she was found to have an  intra ocular pressure of 20 mm Hg. Her previous recorded values of intra ocular pressure were 18 mm Hg and 20 mm Hg. The patient is found to have cup disc ratio of more than 0.6, gonioscopy showed open angle, visual field testing showed Siedel scotoma. What is this condition is known as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the all the features of primary open angle glaucoma with an intra ocular pressure of less than 21 mm Hg. This condition is known as normal tension glaucoma.

Other options:

Option A- Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG)- The following features are needed to diagnose POAG:

  • An intraocular pressure of more than 21 mm Hg on more than one occasion.
  • The presence of optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucoma:
    • A cup:disc ratio of more than 0.5
    • An asymmetry between the cup:disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2
    • Narrowing, notching or pallor of the neuroretinal rim
    • Disc haemorrhages and abnormalities of the blood vessels suggesting enlargement of the optic cup
  • Visual field changes consistent with glaucoma
  • Defects in the retinal nerve fibre layer

Option B- Primary open angle glaucoma suspect- Patients with changes of optic nerve head suggestive of glaucoma but with

  • IOP leass than 21 mm Hg
  • No visual field changes

Option C- Ocular hypertension- Individuals with IOP more than 21 mm Hg physiologically but with

  • No optic nerve head abnormalities
  • No visual field changes

questions.text: You are evaluating the metabolic changes in patients with various conditions. Increased basal metabolic rate will be seen in patients with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in patients with acromegaly.

High energy-requiring states such as fever, pregnancy, pheochromocytoma, adrenergic agonist drugs, cancer, congestive heart failure, acromegaly, polycythemia, and Paget’s disease of the bone are associated with high BMR. Obesity, starvation or anorexia, hypogonadism, Addison's syndrome, and immobilization are associated with low BMR.

BMR is the energy required by an awake individual during rest. It is the minimum energy required to carry out vital functions of the body such as respiration, circulation, etc. 

It is calculated using oxygen consumption, calorific value (energy produced by 1 liter of oxygen), and surface area.

BMR is dependent on various factors:

  • Men have more BMR than women of the same body weight and age because women’s bodies contain proportionally more adipose tissue and fewer muscles. 
  • Elderly people have less BMR as the muscle tissue gets infiltrated with fat as age advances.
  • Low environmental temperature is associated with high BMI.
  • Exercise increases BMR.
  • The thyroid hormone has a direct role in increasing BMR.

questions.text: Which of the following snakes produce neurotoxic venom?
questions.solution:
Cobra and Krait produce neurotoxic venom.

Patients present with vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, and ‘gooseflesh’. Paralysis first presents with ptosis followed by external ophthalmoplegia. Later, paralysis of the muscles of the face, palate, jaws, tongue, and neck can occur. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of the intercostal muscles and diaphragm.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out in a population of 120 persons, of which 20 had the disease. The screening test result was positive for 20 people, of which 15 had the disease. What is the specificity of the test?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the specificity of the test is 95%

  Disease + Disease - Total
Test + 15 (True Positives) 5 (False Positives) 20
Test - 5 (False negatives) 95 (True Negatives) 100
Total 20 100 120

Positive results:

  • Out of the 20 positive results, 15 had the disease
  • So, the number of true positives = 15
  • The remaining 5 people are false positives because they had positive results but did not have the disease

Negative results:

  • The population who got negative results = 120-20 = 100
  • Out of the 100 people with negative results, 5 are false negatives. This is because out of the 20 people who had the disease, 15 had positive results, and the remaining 5 had negative results despite having the disease (i.e. false negatives).
  • So, the remaining 95 (100-5) are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given as follows:

True negatives (TN) / False positives (FP) + True Negatives (TN) × 100

= 95/5+95 × 100

= 95/100 × 100

= 0.95 × 100

Specificity = 95%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of severe headache for 1 week which is not relieved with analgesics. A brain CT was done revealed a suprasellar mass as shown below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This unenhanced CT showing a calcified cystic structure in the suprasellar region, along with dilated ventricles (hydrocephalus), is suggestive of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are relatively benign neoplasms that typically arise in the suprasellar region. They are derived from the remnants of Rathke cleft and have bimodal age distribution.

The two variants of craniopharyngioma are:

  • Adamantinomatous - It is seen in children. Calcification is characteristic of this variety.
  • Papillary - It is seen in adults. Wet keratin nodules are the characteristic histologic feature of this type.

Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Craniopharyngiomas tend not to expand the pituitary fossa unless they become very large, which is a differentiating feature from pituitary macroadenomas.

The image given below shows a T1-weighted MRI brain showing craniopharyngioma in a sagittal view.

Other options:

Option B: Pituitary macroadenomas are seen in the sellar region. Calcifications are mostly absent in contrast to craniopharyngiomas. In addition, on imaging, indentation at the diaphragma sellae gives rise to a snowman/figure of eight appearance/cottage loaf.

The image below shows the snowman appearance seen in pituitary macroadenomas.

Option C: Meningioma is mainly a supratentorial tumor, commonly seen in the parasagittal region.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, recently diagnosed with hypertension, was started on telmisartan 2 weeks ago. On the follow-up visit, his blood pressure was still high and investigations revealed elevated urea and creatinine. His medical history includes diabetes and coronary artery disease. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Ultrasound Doppler of the renal arteries

questions.solution:
This patient diagnosed with hypertension presenting with deranged renal parameters after starting an angiotensin receptor blocker likely is suggestive of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis, for which ultrasound Doppler of the renal arteries is the initial investigation. 

Renal artery stenosis secondary to atherosclerosis is an important cause of renovascular hypertension, occurring due to the occlusion of the proximal part of the renal arteries. The prevalence increases with age, diabetes, and for patients with other vascular conditions such as coronary artery disease, peripheral aortic(as evidenced by aortic bruits), or lower extremity disease.  

Critical levels of stenosis lead to a reduction in perfusion pressure that activates the renin-angiotensin system, reduces sodium excretion, and activates sympathetic adrenergic pathways. These events lead to systemic hypertension and accelerated target organ injury, including left ventricular hypertrophy and renal fibrosis.

Severe or refractory hypertension, carotid or femoral artery bruits, flash pulmonary edema, unexplained deterioration of renal function or deterioration of renal function associated with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin receptor blocker(ARB) should raise the possibility of renovascular hypertension. These agents decrease the glomerular filtration rate in a stenotic kidney owing to efferent renal arteriolar dilation, particularly in bilateral renal artery stenosis. Approximately 50% of patients with renovascular hypertension have an abdominal or flank bruit, due to the stenosed renal arteries.

If renal artery stenosis is suspected imaging studies should be the next step in the evaluation. Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries produces reliable estimates of renal blood flow and offers the opportunity to track a lesion over time. Contrast arteriography remains the gold standard for the evaluation and identification of renal artery lesions.       

Medical therapy should include the use of ACE inhibitors or ARBs, attainment of goal BPs, cessation of tobacco, statins, and aspirin. Follow-up requires surveillance for progressive occlusion manifest by worsening renal function and/or loss of BP control. Renal revascularization is now often reserved for patients failing medical therapy or developing additional complications. 

Other options :

Option A - Estimation of plasma-free metanephrines is done in cases of suspected phaeochromocytoma. Among the presenting manifestations, episodes of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating are typical and constitute a classic triad. The presence of all three manifestations in association with episodic hypertension makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis. 

Option B - Plasma aldosterone: plasma renin activity is estimated in primary hyperaldosteronism, where it is elevated to > 30:1. Primary hyperaldosteronism can be familial or sporadic, caused by an aldosterone-producing adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. The age at the time of diagnosis is generally the third through fifth decade. In patients with primary aldosteronism, increased aldosterone production is independent of the renin-angiotensin system, and the consequences are sodium retention, hypertension and hypokalemia.

Option D - Estimation of 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion is used as a screening test for Cushing's syndrome, which is one of the causes of secondary hypertension. The mechanism of hypertension may be related to stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol and increased secretion of other adrenal steroids. However, there will be other features like truncal obesity, plethoric moon facies, purple striae, proximal muscle weakness, hypokalemic alkalosis, hyperandrogenism, and psychological disturbances.

questions.text: A 24 year old female presents with yellowish discolouration of eyes. LFT showed mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. She started using OCPs recently. What is the expected finding on liver biopsy in this condition?

choices.text: Dark melanin like pigments in hepatocytes
Accumulation of lipofuscin pigment in hepatocytes

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with jaundice,a rise in the level of conjugated bilirubin and usage of OCPS , points to the diagnosis of Dubin Johnson syndrome. Liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the hepatocytes. 

The dark melanin like pigemets are derived from epinephrine metabolites

DJS is an autosomal recessive condition causing defective expression of MRP 2 protein which is important for the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin. The patient has icterus but is otherwise asymptomatic. The icterus might get noticed only during illness, pregnancy or consumption of OCPs.

Liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the hepatocytes. In DJS, there is Increased excretion of coproporphyrin 1 in the urine eventhough the total urinary coproporphyrin remains normal. LFT shows conjugated hyperbilirubinemaia. 

It is a benign condition and generally does not need any active treatment.

Option A: In Rotor syndrome, the liver biopsy is normal. Rotor syndrome is also an autosomal recessive condition causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but it does not present with pigmentation of the liver.

Option C: Accumulation of lipofuscin pigments in hepatocytes is seen in Gilberts syndrome. Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Option D: Lobular and portal inflammation is seen in autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text:
The flow-volume curve after the spirometry of a patient is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

The dotted curve indicates the normal pattern.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an obstructive pattern on the flow-volume curve. So the most likely diagnosis of this patient is bronchial asthma.

The flow-volume curve above shows a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. 

Other options: 

Option A: Myasthenia gravis shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Option B: Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop. 

Option C: Vocal cord paralysis shows a variable upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop.

questions.text: An elderly male with immunocompromised status is admitted to ICU with fever and features of encephalitis. CSF culture is ordered which shows a trophozoite. The provisional diagnosis of granulomatous amebic encephalitis is made. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The likely causative agent to cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis is Balamuthia mandrillaris. 

Balamuthia is a leptomixid free-living amoeba. It exists in the ameboid trophozoite stage and flagellate is absent. It is not associated with acanthopodia as seen in Acanthamoeba species. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall. 

Human beings acquire infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts or through traumatized skin or eyes. Following inhalation, the trophozoites reach the lungs and invade the central nervous system through the bloodstream, producing granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE). 

Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) is a rare but severe central nervous system infection caused by free-living amoebae. The causative agents are Acanthamoeba (most common), Balamuthia mandrillaris, and Sappinia pedata. 

GAE can present with symptoms such as headache, fever, stiff neck, nausea, vomiting, confusion, seizures, and focal neurological deficits. Diagnosis can be challenging and often requires a combination of clinical suspicion, imaging studies (such as MRI), and laboratory tests (such as cerebrospinal fluid analysis).

Treatment for GAE usually involves a combination of antimicrobial agents, including drugs like pentamidine, flucytosine, sulfadiazine, and others. However, the prognosis for GAE is often poor, as the condition can progress rapidly and cause significant neurological damage.

Prevention of GAE involves avoiding exposure to contaminated water sources, using proper water treatment methods, and practicing good hygiene, especially when engaging in activities that may expose the nasal passages to contaminated water.

Other options:

Option A- Angiostrongylus cantonensis is the most common cause of eosinophilic meningitis (cerebral angiostrongyliasis) in humans. in Southeast Asia. It is a nematode (roundworm).

Option B- Naegleria fowleri is mainly associated with primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. The electron microscopy image of the infective form shows rounded pseudopodia called lobopodia. The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is an infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer on cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis. The center of the abscess contains thick brown-colored pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

questions.text: The rate of postmortem cooling is higher in which among the following situations?

choices.text: An adult body kept in a dry environment
A body with excess fat kept in a closed room
A fully clothed body kept under a blanket
A body kept in a well ventilated humid environment

questions.solution:
The rate of post mortem cooling is higher in a body kept in a well ventilated humid environment. 

Moist air is a better conductor of heat than dry air, therefore postmortem cooling is more rapid in a humid environment than dry environment. A body kept in a well ventillated room will cool more rapidly than one kept in a closed room.

Rate of cooling is slow when the body is clothed as clothes are bad conductors of heat. 

Fat is a bad conductor of heat. Fat bodies cool slowly and lean bodies cool rapidly.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Increased difference in the temperature between body and the atmosphere
  • Large body surface area
  • Children and old aged people
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity
  • Body immersed in running water

Rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat
  • Edema
  • Body covered with clothing
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of desmopressin that is used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder that occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It can be given by iv or sc injection, nasal inhalation, or orally. 

Principal cells in the collecting duct have V2 receptors on their basolateral membrane. When stimulated, they increase the insertion rate of water channels - aquaporin2, into the apical membrane. This increases water permeability. V2 receptors also increase the permeability of urea and help in the renal conservation of water.

Activating endothelial V2 receptors by desmopressin or vasopressin increases circulating levels of procoagulant factor VIII and the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding for the past 4 months. She is not on any medications and has a family history of endometrial cancer. On transvaginal ultrasound, the endometrial thickness is 2 mm but a focal area shows 5 mm of endometrial thickness. Which of the following is the gold standard test to diagnose the cause of bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Fractional curettage of the endometrium and endocervix
Dilatation and curettage of the endometrium
Endometrial sampling using Pipelle/ vabra aspirator

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of postmenopausal bleeding, the transvaginal ultrasound shows a focal area with 5 mm of endometrial thickness. The gold standard investigation for focal lesions causing post-menopausal bleeding is hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy. 

In the given scenario the overall endometrial thickness is 2 mm. However, if the overall endometrial thickness would be >4 mm, then the gold standard investigation would be fractional curettage or dilatation and curettage. Since the question only mentions a focal abnormality, hysteroscopy and selective biopsy is a better choice for this patient. 

Menopause is defined as the absence of menstruation for one year after the age of 40 years. But it is usually seen around 45 to 47 years of age. Any vaginal bleeding that occurs after menopause or even after just 6 months of amenorrhea in menopausal age group women is defined as postmenopausal bleeding. 

All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Investigations used for diagnosing the cause of postmenopausal bleeding:

Outpatient procedures - 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation that checks for endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of >4mm calls for further investigation by endometrial biopsy.
  • Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Inpatient procedures - 

  • Fractional curettage (dilatation and curettage) of the endometrial and the endocervical tissue helps to know the site of malignancy, the extent of spread, and also staging of the tumor. It is the best test to perform if cancer is suspected as the cause of bleeding. This requires general anesthesia.
  • Hysteroscopic inspection & selective biopsy is the gold standard procedure to diagnose focal endometrial lesions. It can be performed as an outpatient procedure as well.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A nurse sustained a needlestick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. How long should he be taking the prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg for 4 weeks. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

The protocol followed is :Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28 - day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

Note: The NACO October 2018 guidelines recommend the two drug regimen but the recent MOHFW JAN 2020 recommends the three drug regimen as per WHO December 2018 guidelines as the preferred treatment for PEP in HIV.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with painful intermittent swelling of knee and elbow joints with recurrent throat infections in the recent past. An ASO titre is to be measured for diagnosis. Which type of test is used to measure ASO titre?
questions.solution:
ASO(Anti-streptolysin O) is measured by the latex agglutination test.(Option C)

The given clinical scenario of painful intermittent swelling of multiple joints (migratory polyarthritis) with a recent history of recurrent throat infections is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Group A β-hemolytic streptococci such as streptococcus pyogenes produce hemolysins such as streptolysin-O and streptolysin-S. They cause RBC membrane lysis which is responsible for β-hemolysis in blood agar. 

Antibodies against these hemolysins are formed in the body whose titre is used as a standard marker for retrospective diagnosis of streptococcal infections. An ASO titer of >200 IU/mL is diagnostic of most streptococcal infections except pyoderma and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). It was previously detected by a neutralisation test but is now completely replaced by the latex agglutination and nephelometry methods.

In latex agglutination tests, polystyrene latex particles (0.8–1 μm in diameter) are used as carrier molecules capable of adsorbing several types of antigens. A drop of the patient’s serum (containing antibody) is added to a drop of latex solution coated with the antigen and the card is rotated for uniform mixing. A positive result is indicated by the formation of visible clumps. It is a simple, rapid card test.

Anti-DNase-B antibody titer of more than 300–350 IU/ mL is diagnostic of PSGN and pyoderma. 

Other options -

Option A) Tube agglutination test - Examples are - 

  • Widal test for typhoid fever
  • Standard agglutination test(SAT) for acute brucellosis
  • Coomb’s antiglobulin test
  • All heterophile antibody tests       

Option B) Precipitation test examples are -

  • Slide flocculation tests of syphilis - VDRL and RPR tests
  • Elek’s gel precipitation test - Detecting toxigenic strains of diphtheria 

Option D) An example of a complement fixation test is the Wasserman test, formerly used for serological diagnosis of syphilis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the forearm which appeared 7 months back. New lesions have appeared on the other arm after abrasions at the same site. A skin biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis shows the following histology. What is the structure marked?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lichen planus. The structure marked in the histopathological image of lichen planus is civatte bodies.

Civatte bodies/Colloid bodies are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consist largely of keratin intermediate filaments, and are almost always covered with immunoglobulins. They are found particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. They are usually seen in lichenoid dermatosis.

Lichen planus is the most typical lichenoid dermatosis. It is characterized by idiopathic inflammation of skin and mucosal tissues. It has mostly a chronic course with frequent relapses.

Lichen Planus manifests as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques - which are the 6Ps of lichen planus. It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion), Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).

Histopathology of lichen planus typically shows interface dermatitis, saw toothing, Max Joseph’s space, Civatte or colloid bodies.

The following image shows the histology of Lichen planus with loss of rete ridges, loss of stratum basale, and interface dermatitis.

The following image shows lesions characteristic of lichen planus - Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques:

Squamous cell carcinoma may arise from mucosal and paramucosal lichen planus.

Other options :

Option C: Donovan bodies are characteristic of in granuloma inguinale (also called donovanosis). They are due to macrophages encapsulating Klebsiella granulomatis coccobacilli.
