questions.text: Which of the following is the electrocardiograph changes seen in early stages of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: ST-segment depression with flat T waves
ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression

questions.solution:
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is seen in early stages of acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography findings are usually normal or may show evidence of a pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

Other options:

Option A: ST-segment depression with flat T waves are seen in hypokalemia. Prolongation of QT interval is also seen.

ECG given below shows ST depression and broad flat T waves seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Electrical alternans of P, QRS, and T waves are seen in cardiac tamponade.

ECG given below shows electrical alterans seen in cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

ECG given below shows tall peaked T waves seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old G1P0 woman comes at 20 weeks of gestation for an anomaly scan. The following ultrasound finding is observed. What is true regarding the condition?

AFP - alpha-fetoprotein

choices.text: Screening shows decreased AFP levels in the maternal serum
Fetal adrenal cortex hyperplasia is seen
It is an indication for medical termination of pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given anomaly scan ultrasound image shows an absent cranial calvarium which suggests anencephaly which is an indication for medical termination of pregnancy (option D).

Anencephaly is one of the eugenic reasons for medical termination of pregnancy. Eugenic reasons refers to conditions where the child may be born with serious physical and mental abnormalities incompatible with life such as anencephaly.


Anencephaly is the absence of the cranium and telencephalon above the level of the skull base and the orbits. It results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. 

Screening for anencephaly reveals increased levels of maternal serum AFP and not decreased AFP levels (Option A).

In normal fetuses, due to an intact hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, hypertrophy occurs in the reticular zone of the fetal adrenal cortex. This results in the production of cortisol and dehydroepiandrosterone which is required for placental oestrogen production, which plays an important role in the onset of labor. The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis is absent in anencephaly, leading to the absence of the reticular zone of the fetal adrenal cortex (Option B). Therefore, anencephaly is associated with post-term pregnancy.

Anencephaly results in polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios due to transudation from the exposed meninges, absence of fetal swallowing reflex, and possible suppression of fetal antidiuretic hormone leading to excessive urination (Option C).

Management of anencephaly is termination of pregnancy preferably before 20 weeks of pregnancy since the fetuses are incompatible with life. Fetuses with anencephaly die either in the womb or shortly after birth. Spontaneous preterm delivery may occur due to polyhydramnios or cause post-term pregnancy due to lack of placental oestrogen for spontaneous labour.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A histopathological examination of a bone tumor in a middle-aged female is shown below. Which of the following is the recommended mode of treatment in the early stage for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination shows multi-nucleated osteoclast-type giant cells suggestive of giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma. The recommended mode of treatment in the early stage of osteoclastoma is curettage.

Osteoclastoma is a locally aggressive tumor affecting the ends of the long bones (epiphysis), especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. It is seen in patients of the age group 20 to 45 years. It can also occur in conjunction with Paget’s disease of the bone and in association with focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

Patients can present with pain, increasing mass, and pathological fractures. It can extend into the soft tissue and present as a soft tissue mass.

Grossly, it appears as meaty, purplish tissue with soft yellow areas. Histology shows osteoclast-like giant cells along with scattered round and spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. Radiological findings are eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesions with a narrow zone of transition giving it a soap-bubble appearance.

Treatment includes intralesional curettage for stage 1 and 2 lesions, whereas stage 3 lesions are treated with a thorough curettage. Anti-RANKL antibodies such as denosumab can be used to treat advanced stage 3 lesions.

Other options:

Option B: Osteoid osteoma is a small benign tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It most commonly affects diaphyses of long bones such as the femur. Treatment comprises CT-guided radiofrequency ablation, which resolves the symptoms. 

Options C and D: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The preferred method of treatment of osteosarcoma is wide resection and reconstruction. This is mainly owing to the possibility of limb salvage and multi-agent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with agents like doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate. 

Treatment of Ewing's sarcoma includes pre-operative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin, etoposide, and wide surgical excision.

questions.text: A woman with cervical cancer is posted to undergo the procedure shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the procedure?

choices.text: Not useful if the transformation zone cannot be completely visualized
Suitable only for lesions of ectocervix without endocervical involvement
Has no bearing on the future pregnancies
Can be both diagnostic and therapeutic

questions.solution:
The given procedure is conization, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic for cancer cervix.

Conization is a gynecological procedure performed in an operation theatre under anesthesia, where the entire outer margin of the cervix and endocervical lining short of the internal os is removed.

Indications for the procedure are : 

  • When the transformation zone is not completely visualized (option A)
  • Endocervical dysplasia (option B)
  • When there is a discrepancy in findings between cytology, colposcopy and biopsy
  • When micro invasion is suspected

Since it provides tissue for histopathological study in suspected cases of cancer cervix, it is diagnostic. It is also considered therapeutic in Stage IA1 cervical cancer.

Complications of the procedure include bleeding, sepsis, cervical stenosis, abortion and preterm labor (option C).

questions.text: You are a researcher conducting a study in an urban young population regarding skin melanoma. You formulate a hypothesis on etiology. Which of the following studies is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis?
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis.

Descriptive statistics is a type of statistical method which helps to describe, organise or summarise the data. It refers only to the actual data.

Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease, including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population. Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology. There is no intervention in this type of study. it is merely observational.

It involves the following: 

  • Defining the study population 
  • Defining the disease under the study
  • Describing the disease by parameters like time, place and person
  • Measuring the disease
  • Comparing it with known indices and
  • Formulating an etiological hypothesis.

The formulated hypothesis should specify the following:   

  • The study population 
  • The cause which is taken into consideration
  • Expected outcome
  • Dose-response relationship
  • Time-response relationship

Types of epidemiological studies:

Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.

  1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population.
  2. Analytical studies - go further by analysing the relationship between health status and other variables.
    • Ecological studies
    • Cross-sectional studies
    • Case-control studies
    • Cohort studies

Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences.

  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials      

Other options:

Option A: Analytical study is a type of epidemiological study and its objective is to test the hypothesis. 

Option B: Experimental studies involve making changes in the experimental group while no changes are made in the control group and comparing the outcome. 

Option C: A cross-sectional study or prevalence study is a form of observational study. A cross-section of the population at one point in time is examined and it reflects the results of the whole population. 

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of food, which is followed by self-induced vomiting. Her BMI is 22. What is the first line pharmacological treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting is bulimia nervosa. Fluoxetine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for her condition. Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment for bulimia nervosa. 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Cyproheptadine can be used in treatment of restrictive anorexia nervosa. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. 

Option C: Mirtazapine is used in major depressive disorder. It increases appetite and causes significant weight gain.

Option D: Buspirone is used in generalized anxiety disorder or social anxiety disorder.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1-cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. A diagnosis of insulinoma was made. Which of the following is not a component of the classical Whipple's triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Increased levels of 72-hour-fasting insulin is not a part of classic Whipple's triad.

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma:

  1. Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  2. Plasma glucose levels of <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL
  3. Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour-fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Insulinomas having diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals and octreotide or diazoxide.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female patient presents with webbing of her neck and a low posterior hairline. On examination, there was limited neck mobility and bilateral elevated scapula. Her X-ray neck is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an xray neck showing fusion of C6, C7, and T1 vertebrae suggests a diagnosis of Klippel-Feil syndrome. 

Klippel-Feil syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by failure of segmentation of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis, resulting in fusion of at least two cervical segments. Congenital fusion can occur at any level in the cervical spine but mostly occurs in the upper cervical spine. It is sometimes associated with fetal alcohol syndrome.

The classical triad of children with Klippel-Feil syndrome is a short neck with various degrees of neck webbing, low posterior hairline and limited neck mobility. 

It is associated with other skeletal and extraskeletal abnormalities such as scoliosis, renal abnormalities, (most commonly unilateral renal agenesis), Sprengel deformity(unilateral congenital elevation of scapula), deafness and congenital heart disease such as ventricular septal defect(VSD). Hand abnormalities include syndactyly, thumb hypoplasia and extra digits.

Symptoms are mainly restriction of neck movements in the involved segments, hypermobility of the adjacent segments and neurological deficits.

For asymptomatic patients, treatment is conservative with parents warned about contact sports since sudden neurological compromise can occur after minor trauma. Children with symptoms may need cervical fusion. 

Other options -

Option A - Poland syndrome is a sporadic condition characterised by unilateral hypoplasia of the whole upper limb girdle including the shoulder and chest wall(ribs, pectoral muscles, breast tissue, nipple). The corresponding hand shows brachydactyly(small digits), syndactyly(fused digits) and symphalangism(fused phalanges, absent interphalangeal joints). 

Option C - Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder characterized by an XO aneuploidy in a female with short stature, webbing of the neck due to resolution of cystic hygroma, low posterior highline and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Other features include streak ovaries causing amenorrhea and infertility with a normal vagina, uterus, and prepubertal female genitalia. There is no fusion of cervical spine or bilateral elevated scapulae as in Klippel-Feil syndrome.

Option D - Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis(DISH), also known as Forestier’s disease is a common condition seen in late middle-aged/ elderly males characterised by hyperostosis seen at multiple sites, but mainly in the spine at enthesis sites (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone). Most commonly involves T7 to T12. Cervical and lumbar hyperostosis may also be seen. It is not a congenital condition as well as the absence of bilateral elevated scapulae, neck webbing and low posterior hairline differentiates from Klippel Feil syndrome. Patients might even be asymptomatic and the condition may be found incidentally.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient was diagnosed with carcinoma of the breast and is set to undergo radical mastectomy with dissection of levels 1, 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Which of the following represents level 3 lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes marked as 1 belong to the level 3 axillary nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to or above the upper border of the pectoralis minor

 

Another method of axillary lymph node classification, as shown in the image below, is based on the anatomical regions that the specific nodes drain.

It can be classified into 5 groups- apical, central, lateral, anterior, and posterior. The apical group receives lymph from the other 4 groups, as well as from the upper part of the breast on the same side.

The image below demonstrates this method of lymph node grouping-

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

questions.text: An eight-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body along with a history of wide-based, unsteady gait. On examination, serum electrolytes are normal and urine is positive for neutral amino acids. The pattern of inheritance of the disease is given in the image below.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra-like symptoms with autosomal recessive inheritance as shown in the image is suggestive of Hartnup disease. It is due to a tryptophan transport defect.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to a mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on Chromosome 5. This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia(wide-based unsteady gait), tremors, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, distinguishing it from pellagra. Indican can also be present in the urine, produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Treatment involves supplementation with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.  

Other options :

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase defect is seen in acute intermittent porphyria, which is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It presents with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. There will be elevated aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Option C: Methylcobalamin formation defect results in methylmalonic acidemia, which follows autosomal recessive inheritance. The clinical manifestations would include vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures. 

Option D: Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency results in tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Patients present with corneal inflammation, painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and mental retardation.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheezing, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed a bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following finding marked by an arrow. What are these structures made of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals, lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma. The structures marked by the yellow arrow in the image are Charcot–Leyden crystals and these are made of an eosinophilic-derived protein called galectin 10.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic-derived protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient suffers from diabetes and hypertension. He regularly takes metformin, glimepiride, amlodipine, and losartan. He now presents to the clinic with ankle swelling and gingival hyperplasia. Which of the following drug is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Gingival hyperplasia and ankle swelling are side-effects of calcium channel blockers like amlodipine. 

Ankle edema occurs due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries present in the dependent parts of the body. This is due to reflex constriction of postcapillary vessels. Other common side effects of amlodipine include headache, dizziness and abdominal pain.

Option A - Metformin usually has side effects like bloating, abdominal pain, anorexia, and mild diarrhea. It does not cause hypoglycemia except in cases of an overdose.

Option B - Glimepiride tends to cause weight gain in most diabetics. Symptoms like nausea, vomiting, flatulence, and headache are mild and infrequent. Dangerously low blood glucose is a common but sometimes fatal problem. Due to this, patients taking glimepride should check their blood glucose levels regularly. 

Option C - Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that can cause orthostatic hypotension, oliguria and even hyperkalemia. These symptoms are generally rare as ARBs are well tolerated.

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with diarrhea, high fever, chest pain, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pleural effusion and patchy pulmonary infiltrates. The gram staining of the pleural fluid showed the following organism. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli point towards the diagnosis of legionnaire's disease for which the drug of choice is azithromycin. 

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhoea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Respiratory quinolones such as levofloxacin can also be used as alternatives to macrolides.

The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients. 

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.


B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are considered ineffective.

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding the structure marked as * in the given image EXCEPT?

choices.text: It can obstructs the drainage of maxillary sinus
It can originate from either anterior or posterior ethmoid cells
It is related to the lateral wall of maxillary sinus
It is an anatomical variant of normal ethmoid cells

questions.solution:
The structure marked as * in the above image are Haller cells and they are related to the roof of the maxillary sinus.

Haller cells are ethmoidal air cells ( mostly anterior) either found in the orbit floor or the roof of the maxillary sinus. These cells can be pneumatised from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells ( Option B ). It is an anatomical variant of normal ethmoid cells and can be found in about 30% of the population ( Option D ). When Haller cells become enlarged then they can encroach on the ethmoid infundibulum, and decrease the drainage from the maxillary sinus ( Option A ) causing sinusitis. Their presence also sometimes complicates Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS).

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain:

  • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge.
  • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.
  • Supraorbital cells
  • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess.
  • Haller cells 

Posterior cells - They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. 

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: Which of the following is the content of Littre's hernia?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the content of Littre's hernia.

Littre's hernia is a rare inguinal hernia where Meckel's diverticulum is the content of the sac. Meckel’s diverticulum is the embryological remnant of the distal 1/3rd of the vitellointestinal duct.

Other options:

Option A: Hernia with hydrocele is Gibbon's hernia.

Option B: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Maydl's hernia contains two loops of bowel arranged like a 'W'.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T1-weighted image as the CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, but the most classic ones are T1- and T2-weighted imaging.

In T1 images, CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

In T2 images, CSF is bright/hyperintense, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. (water is white on T2, so is CSF)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pain in the great toe and was diagnosed to be a case of gout. The physician decides to prescribe a drug X that increases the renal excretion of uric acid in combination with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. Which is the drug X prescribed?
questions.solution:
The drug X is Lesinurad. 

Lesinurad is a uricosuric drug that increases the renal excretion of uric acid by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid through the URAT-1 and OAT-4 transporters. It is not used as monotherapy, always used in combination preferably with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor because the risk of acute renal failure and nephrolithiasis is more common with monotherapy.

Uricosuric drugs help in increasing the excretion of uric acid. Other drugs include:

  • Probenecid- It inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting organic acid transporters (OATs), principally URAT-1.
  • Benzbromarone- It increases uric acid secretion by reversibly inhibiting the urate–anion exchanger in the proximal tubule
  • Sulfinpyrazone- It inhibits the organic anion transporter that is involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules.

Other treatment options for gout:

  • Drugs that inhibit urate formation- These drugs inhibit urate formation by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase - Allopurinol and Febuxostat
  • Uricase drugs that oxidize uric acid to more soluble allantoin - Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • Prevention of inflammatory responses to crystals - Colchicine (interferes with microtubule and spindle formation, affecting cell division and altering neutrophil motility)

questions.text: A person cycles for 4 hours on an empty stomach, causing glycogen to break down and release glucose. After reaching home, he has a full meal, leading to glucose being stored as glycogen. Which of the following enzymes is used in both these processes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the person undergoes glycogenolysis to break down glycogen and release glucose and then undergoes glycogenesis in which glucose gets stored as glycogen. Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.

The substrate for glycogenolysis is glycogen and during this process, glycogen is first converted into glucose-1-phosphate by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase. This is a rate-limiting step in the process. Glucose-1-phosphate is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme phosphoglucomutase and eventually, glucose is obtained from glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme phosphatase.

During glycogenesis, glucose is phosphorylated to glucose-6-phosphate, catalyzed by hexokinase in muscle and glucokinase in the liver. Glucose-6-phosphate is isomerized to glucose-1-phosphate by phosphoglucomutase. UDP-glucose is synthesized from glucose-1-phosphate and UTP by UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase. A protein named glycogenin is the primer acting as an acceptor of glucose residues. This is glycosylated further by UDP-glucose. Glycogenin further catalyzes the transfer of seven glucose residues from UDP-Glucose, in 1 → 4 linkages, to form a glycogen primer. This in turn serves as the substrate for the enzyme, glycogen synthase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogen synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha 1,6 glucosidase is involved in glycogenolysis alone.

Option B: Glycogen Phosphorylase is involved in glycogenolysis alone.

Option D: Glycogen synthase is involved in glycogenesis alone.

questions.text: What is the principal mechanism of action of clomiphene in the treatment of infertility?

choices.text: Prevention of conversion of androgen to estrogen
Enhancement of ovarian sensitivity to FSH
Inhibition of estrogen binding at the pituitary
Proliferation of the secretory endometrium of the uterus

questions.solution:
Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) commonly used in the treatment of infertility, particularly in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It acts by competitively inhibiting estrogenic binding at the pituitary gland.

Clomiphene is primarily used for the treatment of anovulation in the setting of an intact hypothalamic-pituitary axis and adequate estrogen production (e.g., PCOS) or to induce superovulation in women with unexplained infertility. By blocking feedback inhibition of estrogen at the pituitary and hypothalamus, clomiphene increases gonadotropin secretion and stimulates ovulation. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

Clomiphene induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40–50% of patients conceive. However, abortions are common due to luteal phase defects. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs in <1% of cases. Co-administration with dexamethasone leads to better outcomes. In resistant cases, tamoxifen 20–40 mg daily for 5 days should be tried.

Other options: 

Option A: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, prevents the conversion of androgen to estrogen. It is used in the induction of ovulation and management of breast cancer in postmenopausal females.

Options B and D: Clomiphene does not increase ovarian sensitivity to FSH and does not cause proliferation of the secretory endometrium of the uterus

questions.text: A patient presenting with anal fistula was seen to have a cobblestone appearance of the intestine on diagnostic colonoscopy, which of the following drugs is the best-suited induction therapy of choice for the patient before suggestion of surgery.
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with anal fistula along with a cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is likely to be suffering from severe Crohn's disease and Infliximab is the induction monotherapy of choice for this stage before suggestion of surgery.

Infliximab is a chimeric IgG1 monoclonal antibody against TNF-α. It binds with high affinity to TNF-α and prevents the cytokine from binding to its receptors. Infliximab, given at a dose of 5 mg/kg through IV infusion every 6–8 weeks, reduces acute flare-ups in about two-thirds of patients with moderate-to-severe Crohn’s disease and also helps in closing entero-cutaneous fistulas linked to Crohn’s disease. As induction therapy, these agents lead to symptom improvement in about 60% of cases within roughly 14 days, achieving remission in about 30% of the patients.

Adverse effects of the drug include:

  • Acute and subacute infection resulting from suppression of the inflammatory response.
  • Development of antibodies against the drug ( Adalimumab and certolizumab are humanised mab, hence there is less chance of development of immune response against them )
  • Re-activation of latent tuberculosis
  • Drug-induced lupus
  • non-melanoma skin cancer
  • multiple sclerosis-like syndrome 
  • Increased incidence of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma 

Administration of infliximab is contraindicated in congestive heart failure patients.

Infliximab is also used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis; it is used in combination with methotrexate in patients who do not respond to methotrexate alone. 

NOTE : The FDA suggests testing candidates of infliximab therapy for latent tuberculosis using purified protein derivative. Patients testing positive should receive prophylactic treatment for latent tuberculosis.

Other options: 

Option A: 5-alpha salicylic acid or mesalamine-based therapy is used as a first-line therapy for mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis. 5-ASA treatments are mostly no longer used to maintain remission in Crohn’s disease because they mainly target surface inflammation in the mucosa, with limited impact on deeper inflammation, affecting long-term outcomes.

Option C: Azathioprine is an immunomodulatory pro-drug that impairs purine biosynthesis. It is used as an adjunct therapy in both inflammatory bowel diseases. Azathioprine or mercaptopurine may take weeks to months to show a clinical response, so other drugs like mesalamine, glucocorticoids, or biologics are preferred for immediate relief.

Option D: Cyclosporine is an inhibitor of calcineurin and a potent immunomodulator, but the high frequency of significant adverse effects limits its use as a first-line medication

questions.text: The ultrasound scan of a pregnant woman given below shows the following finding. Which other ultrasound finding is likely to be seen in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows spina bifida. The other ultrasound sign likely to be seen in this fetus is the lemon sign.

Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for detecting this condition.

 

Banana sign: An abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum along with effacement of the cisterna magna produces this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

The given image shows a banana sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: The structures shown in the below image are found in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in meningioma.

Meningioma is a benign tumor arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid layer and is an intradural extramedullary tumor. 

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Meningiomas. 

Other options:

Option A: Russell bodies are cytoplasmic globular inclusions that are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option C: Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei and are seen in Schwanomma.

Option D: Call-Exner bodies are diagnostic gland-like immature follicles that are filled with an acidophilic material and are seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

questions.text:
A patient presents with episodes of vertigo, hearing loss in the left ear, and a ringing sensation in the ear. PTA findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following structures produces the ear fluid accumulated in this condition?

PTA - Pure tone audiometry
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of episodic vertigo,  hearing loss, and tinnitus. Then, the Pure tone audiometry (PTA) revealing sensorineural hearing loss and showing 'rising' curve is suggestive of Meniere's disease. Endolymph is responsible for the pathophysiology and it is produced by stria vascularis.

Endolymph is the fluid that fills the membranous labyrinth in the ear. It is rich in potassium ions and secreted by special cells in the stria vascularis of the cochlea and the dark cells in the utricle and near the ampullated ends of semicircular ducts. There are two theories about its flow: longitudinal and radial. The longitudinal flow passes through the endolymphatic duct and is absorbed by the endolymphatic sac, while the stria vascularis absorb the radial flow. 

Meniere's disease occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph leading to increased volume and distension of the endolymphatic system. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness of the ear. 

Rinne's test is positive and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected resulting in a 'rising' curve. Later in disease progression, higher frequencies are affected leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text: A 2-year-old febrile child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. Which of the following conditions may also be caused by the organism implicated in this child's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a young child with fever and a rash is strongly suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie A group of viruses. Coxsackie A group viruses are also responsible for herpangina. 

Coxsackie viruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by coxsackie A viruses include hand, foot, and mouth disease, herpangina, aseptic meningitis, and minor respiratory infections.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fevercharacterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and vesicular rashes of the palms and soles, which heal without crusting.

Herpangina is severe febrile vesicular pharyngitis which presents as acute onset fever, sore throat and odynophagia. Lesions are present on the soft palate, anterior pillars of the tonsils, and uvula. In contrast to herpes stomatitis, enteroviral herpangina is not associated with gingivitis.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include pleurodynia, myocarditis, pericarditis, juvenile diabetes, and orchitis. 

Pleurodynia or epidemic myalgia or Bornholm disease is viral myalgia defined by the fever and abrupt onset of stabbing chest pain.

The following images show rashes in hand, foot, and mouth disease-

 

Image showing herpangina-

Other options-
 
Option B: Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an important differential diagnosis of oral ulcers. It is characterized by lesions on the hard and soft palate, gingiva, tongue, lips and facial area. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus, mostly HSV-1.
 
Option C: Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus, usually serotypes 3 and 7. It tends to occur in outbreaks (swimming pool conjunctivitis) and is characterized by febrile pharyngitis and conjunctivitis.
 
Option D: Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by a pox virus. It produces dome-shaped, pink pearly wart-like umbilicated lesions, with a dimple at the center. Lesions are found singly or in clusters, anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles. Genital lesions are seen in adults.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presented with a diminution of vision and was diagnosed to have a moderate visual impairment. According to NPCBVI, this condition is defined as:

NPCBVI: National program for control of blindness and visual impairment

choices.text: Visual acuity < 6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 3/60 in the better eye with available correction

questions.solution:
As per the NPCBVI guidelines, moderate visual impairment is defined as the visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with correction. 

Refractive error is the main cause of visual impairment in ages 0-49 years followed by cataracts, amblyopia and corneal opacity. However, in the age group >50 years, cataract is the major cause followed by refractive errors and surgical complications of cataract. 

Definitions of blindness and visual impairment as per NPCBVI: 

Blindness Presenting visual acuity < 3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Early visual impairment (EVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with available correction
Moderate visual impairment (MVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with available correction
Moderate severe visual impairment (MSVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/18-3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Severe visual impairment (SVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Functional low vision

The visual functioning is impaired even after standard refractive correction.

Visual acuity <6/18 to light perception or

a visual field of fewer than 10 degrees from the point of fixation in people able to use the vision for planning and execution of tasks.
Blindness(BCVA/Pinhole <3/60)  Best-corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye

Cataract was the principal cause of blindness, severe visual impairment, and moderate visual impairment followed by corneal opacity, cataract surgical complications, posterior segment disorders and glaucoma.

For early visual impairment, the most important cause is a refractive error. Principal causes of severe visual impairment other than cataracts were cataract surgical complications and other posterior segment diseases.

questions.text:
A term infant is born via vaginal delivery with meconium staining of liquor. The infant presents with respiratory distress shortly after birth, characterized by tachypnea, cyanosis, and chest retractions. Coarse crackles are heard on auscultation. CXR reveals patchy infiltrates and coarse streaking in both lung fields. What is the infant at increased risk for due to this condition?

CXR: Chest X-Ray

choices.text: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS), characterized by clinical features of respiratory distress, evidence of meconium-stained liquor, and characteristic CXR features of patchy infiltrates and coarse streaking in both lung fields. Infants with MAS are at increased risk of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

MAS occurs in some term and post-term infants. The aspirated meconium may block smaller airways leading to tachypnea, grunting, and cyanosis. The chest radiograph shows patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of lung fields, increased anteroposterior diameter, and flattening of the diaphragm. It commonly resolves within 72 hours, while a few babies may require assisted ventilation.

Meconium aspiration syndrome can lead to several complications, one of which is PPHN. PPHN occurs when there is elevated pulmonary vascular resistance after birth, resulting in inadequate oxygenation of blood and subsequent systemic hypoxemia.

Given below is a CXR of a neonate with meconium aspiration syndrome: 

Other options 

Option A: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a self-limiting disorder occurring due to delayed clearance of lung fluid. Chest radiograph will reveal prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the intralobar fissures. It is more common in twin gestation, maternal asthma, precipitous delivery, and cesarean delivery without labor.

Option B: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery. It is not a complication of MAS.

Option C: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a chronic lung disease that primarily affects premature infants who have received prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. This neonate is a term infant and BPD is not a direct complication of MAS.

questions.text: A man accused of stabbing an elderly woman was brought for forensic examination. Teichmann test was done on his clothes to detect the blood stains. What are the microchemical findings?
questions.solution:
The microchemical findings of Teichmann test are hemin crystals or hematin chloride crystals.

Teichmann or Hemin crystal test is used to detect bloodstains. The stain used glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas. The reaction is negative if the stain is old, is washed or treated by chemicals, presence of too much salt, moisture in acid and overheating.

Other options:

Option A: Choline iodide crystals are seen in Florence test. It is used to detect the presence of semen. The stain used is 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water). If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option B: Hemochromogen crystals are seen in  Takayama test. It is a microchemical test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used is Takayama reagent (Sodium hydroxide, pyridine, glucose). If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes. This test is more reliable and gives positive results with old stains also but not a definitive test to detect blood stains.

Option D: Calcium oxalate crystals are seen in cases of ethylene glycol intoxication, acute uric acid nephropathy and drugs like acyclovir, indinavir.

The below image shows the microscopy findings of tests used for sperm and blood stains.

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 30 year old woman was attending follow up checkup for ovarian cyst. Her only medication history is an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) that she has been regularly taking for the past few years. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows a well-demarcated 3 cm hypoechoic lesion in the liver.  She was referred for further imaging, CT scan image given below. What is the most appropriate advice to give to the patient?

choices.text: Stop OCP and repeat imaging in 6 months
Continue OCP and no follow up needed
Percutaneous liver biopsy for further evaluation

questions.solution:
The given CT shows hepatic adenoma. Stopping OCPs and repeat imaging after 6 months is advised for hepatic adenoma less than 5cm in size

The first step in management of a Hepatic Adenoma (HA) is to stop OCPs or hormonal IUDs all of which increase the size of the tumor. In women who are asymptomatic, HAs<5 cm in size can be managed conservatively because it is unlikely to rupture or undergo malignant transformation. Because there is a risk of increase in size, these patients should be followed up regularly with repeat imaging at a 6 month interval for up to 2 years.

Hepatic adenomas, also referred to as hepatocellular adenomas, are benign liver tumors. They are well-defined, vascular lesions, which are generally solitary. They are almost always seen in women between the age of 25 and 50 years and are associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill. Most are found incidentally on imaging, although some may present with upper abdominal pain caused by local compression, rupture, or bleeding. Up to 10% of these tumors can develop into hepatocellular carcinoma.

On CT, uncomplicated adenomas are usually homogeneous, with a well-defined margin. They enhance markedly and uniformly during the arterial phase and then merge with the surrounding liver during the portal phase.

Option C. Biopsy is recommended if hepatocellular carcinoma is suspected.

Option D. Surgical resection is recommended when the HA is symptomatic or size is > 5 cm due to increased risk of malignant transformation.

questions.text:
During your ward rounds, a clinician demonstrates percussion over the chest wall. A dull note is elicited on an area corresponding to the sternocostal surface of the heart, which is not covered by the lungs. Which chambers of the heart mainly form the sternocostal surface?

RA-Right Atrium, LA-Left atrium, RV-Right Ventricle, LV-Left Ventricle
questions.solution:
The sternocostal surface of the heart is mainly formed by RA and RV.

Surfaces of the heart:

Sternocostal/Anterior surface: It is mainly formed by RA and RV, and partly by LV and Left auricle. The LA is not seen on this surface as it is covered by the aorta and pulmonary trunk. Most of this surface is covered by lungs, but a part of it lying beneath the cardiac notch of the left lung is not covered by the lungs; this uncovered part is called the area of superficial cardiac dullness as it elicits a dull note on percussion. 

Diaphragmatic/Inferior surface: It rests on the central tendon of the diaphragm. It's formed in its left 2/3 by LV and right 1/3 by RV. It is traversed by a posterior interventricular groove. 

Left surface/Base: It is formed mostly by LV and at the upper end, by left auricle. It is crossed by the coronary sulcus in its upper part. It is related to the left phrenic nerve, left pericardiophrenic vessels, and pericardium.

questions.text: A patient with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction( HFrEF) is curious about Sacubitril-Valsartan after reading about its benefits in reducing mortality in the PARADIGM trial. Looking at the diagram below, identify the sites where this combination drug acts.
questions.solution:
C & E are the correct sites of action of Sacubitril-Valsartan.

Based on its mechanism of action, Sacubitril-Valsartan acts on two sites of the RAAS pathway:

  • Site C: This site represents the binding of angiotensin II to the AT1R. Valsartan's blockage of AT1R prevents angiotensin II from exerting its harmful effects.
  • Site E: This site represents the degradation of NPs by neprilysin. Sacubitril's inhibition of neprilysin increases NP levels, contributing to the drug's benceficial effects.

The combination of sacubitril and valsartan increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and lowers blood pressure. Sacubitril combined with valsartan to treat heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor - marked as E. It reduces the breakdown of natriuretic peptides such as ANP, BNP, and CNP, thereby increasing their levels. Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker, marked as C, which lowers blood pressure. 

The drug combination is referred to as an angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor/ARNI. It lowers vascular resistance and increases blood flow. It should not be used with an ACE inhibitor or when there is a history of angioedema during ACE inhibitor or ARB use. The combination is approved for use in chronic heart failure. Sacubitril/valsartan combination in the ratio 1:1 was approved by the FDA for chronic heart failure on 7th July 2015.

Neprilysin: This enzyme breaks down natriuretic peptides (NPs), which have vasodilatory, natriuretic, and diuretic effects. By inhibiting neprilysin, Sacubitril increases the levels of NPs in the body, leading to beneficial effects on blood pressure, fluid balance, and mortality.
Angiotensin II type-1 receptor (AT1R): This receptor mediates the harmful effects of angiotensin II, a hormone that constricts blood vessels and promotes inflammation and fibrosis. Valsartan, the ARB component of Sacubitril-Valsartan, blocks AT1R, preventing angiotensin II from binding and exerting its detrimental effects.

Other options:

Option A: Omapatrilat is a dual inhibitor of neutral endopeptidase and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). It decreases angiotensin II and increases atrial and brain natriuretic peptide, promoting vasodilation, diuresis, and anti-hypertrophic effect.

Option B and D: No combination of B & D or C & D are currently recommended.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used by obstetricians:
questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigleys forceps, which is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in caesarean sections.

The instrument is light, about a third of the weight of an ordinary long-curved forceps. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Other options:

Kielland forceps:

It is a long almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has got a sliding lock which facilitates correction of asynclitism of the head. One small knob on each blade is directed towards the occiput.

Pipers forceps:

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Tucker Mclane forceps:

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A young woman is taking regular oral contraceptive pills. Additional contraceptive measures will be required if there is concomitant use of:
questions.solution:
Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and can cause increased metabolism of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) leading to contraceptive failure. Hence, additional contraceptive measures will be required if there is concomitant use of phenytoin with OCPs.

Ciprofloxacin, omeprazole, and grapefruit juice are enzyme inhibitors that inhibit the degradation of OCPs and increase their duration of action.

  • Carbamazepine
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Phenobarbitone

CYP 450 enzyme inhibitors:

  • Sodium valproate
  • SSRIs - fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline
  • Azole antifungals - ketoconazole, itraconazole, fluconazole
  • Erythromycin, clarithromycin
  • Ciprofloxacin
