questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diarrhoea, steatorrhea, low-grade fever, abdominal pain and joint pains.  A duodenal biopsy revealed the following. Which among the following options is the most effective management ?

choices.text: Oral tetracycline for 3 months with folic acid replacement
IV Ceftriaxone for 14 days followed by oral cotrimoxazole

questions.solution:
From the clinical features and biopsy findings, the patient is suffering from Whipples disease. The most effective management is IV meropenem or ceftriaxone for 2 weeks followed by cotrimoxazole for an year

The morphologic hallmark of whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Whipple's disease is a chronic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei, classically presents as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, intermittent fever, weight loss, arthralgia/arthritis with neurological(cognitive changes progressing to dementia, personality and mood alterations, hypothalamic involvement and supranuclear ophthalmoplegia) and cardiological involvement (endocarditis, congestive heart failure, embolic events, aneurysms).

Another approach is to initially administer CNS-optimized doses of intravenous ceftriaxone (2 g every 12 hours) or meropenem (2 g every 8 hours) for a period of 2 to 4 weeks. Subsequently, treatment can involve oral doxycycline, or a combination of minocycline and hydroxychloroquine.

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with complaints of shortness of breath, chest pain and cough. The following catheter is being used to evaluate the patient for pulmonary hypertension. Identify the catheter.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-Ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter and is used to diagnose and evaluate pulmonary artery hypertension.

The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. It contains 4 internal lumens. The distal port is used to measure PAP (pulmonary artery pressure) while the 2nd port is used to measure CVP (central venous pressure).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is a diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is passed through the central vein, into the right atrium and the right ventricle, and then is finally placed in the pulmonary artery.

The indications include:

  • Evaluation of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Measurement of pressures in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery
  • Assessment of etiology and volume status in shock
  • Assessment of congenital heart disease, cardiac shunts, and right-sided valvular disease

Complications :

  • Catheterization related:
    1. Arrhythmias, ventricular fibrillation
    2. Right bundle branch block, complete heart block
  • Catheter residence related:
    1. Mechanical, catheter knots
    2. Thromboembolism
    3. Pulmonary infarction
    4. Infection, endocarditis
    5. Endocardial damage, cardiac valve injury
    6. Pulmonary artery rupture
    7. Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Others:
    1. Misinterpretation of data
    2. Misuse of equipment

Other options:

All the other catheters mentioned are used for establishing a central venous line for long-term total parenteral nutrition, medications, etc.

The given image shows a triple lumen catheter (option B):

 

The given image shows a peripherally inserted central catheter (Option C). It can be inserted via peripheral veins in pediatric patients.

 

The given image shows double lumen catheter (Option D).

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound. Past history is notable for one episode of acute pancreatitis. An aspirate from the cyst is likely to show:

choices.text: Low amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
Low amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels

questions.solution:
An aspirate from a pancreatic pseudocyst is likely to show high amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. It is also associated with the absence of mucin.

Pancreatic pseudocysts are non-necrotic fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging follow-up of pancreatitis. They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction.

The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. It presents with abdominal pain and epigastric mass. CT is usually done in the evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Observation is the preferred treatment in cases where the size of the pseudocyst is less than 6 cm and arises from the tail of the pancreas. Interventions are required when it is complicated with infection, large size causing mass effect, diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm, recurrence following previous resection.

Treatment includes:

  • Open surgical debridement
  • Cystenterostomy
  • Endoscopic cyst-gastrostomy
  • Percutaneous drainage
  • Octreotide infusion (decreases the amount of pancreatic secretions)

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid, and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation:

  • Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (IEP):
    • APFC- acute peripancreatic fluid collection. Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst- non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotizing pancreatitis:
    • ANC- acute necrotic collection. Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • WON- walled-off necrosis. Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

Note: High levels of CEA is suggestive of mucinous neoplasm.

questions.text: A 50-year-old  female with MEN2A develops a lump in her thyroid gland. Given below is the histologic image of the thyroid biopsy of this patient.  The cells causing this tumour originate from?
questions.solution:
The above histologic biopsy image of a patient with MEN2A  shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is said to arise from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. During embryological development, these cells originate from the neural crest cells and the ultimobranchial body of the Fourth pharyngeal pouch.

The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

The 4th pharyngeal pouch develops a small diverticulum medial to the main pouch called the ultimobranchial body. The ultimobranchial body is later incorporated into the thyroid gland and its cells give rise to the parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland. These cells secrete a hormone called calcitonin that is involved in the regulation of the calcium level in the blood.

The following are the derivatives of each pharyngeal pouch respectively .

1st Pouch
  • Tympanic cavity (middle ear cavity)
  • Auditory tube (eustachian tube) 
2nd Pouch
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Tonsillar fossa
3rd Pouch
  • Inferior parathyroid glands 
  • Thymus
4th Pouch
  • Superior parathyroid glands 
  • Ultimobranchial body - gives rise to parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid gland

The Parafollicular C-cells are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency following a stab injury to the abdomen. His pulse rate is 125/min, BP is 86/58 mmHg. He was visibly anxious and confused. Urine output was monitored and found to be 8mL/hr.  What percent of blood volume is he likely to have lost?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario following a stab injury with tachycardia (125/min) and hypotension (86/58 mm Hg) is suggestive of hypovolemic shock. Presence of tachycardia and hypotension points toward class III hemorrhagic shock (moderate) which corresponds to a total blood loss of 30-40%.

Classification of hemorrhagic shock:

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30     30–40     >40
Pulse rate <100 >100   >120     >140

Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock and to some degree is a component of all other types of shock. Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock Reduced circulating blood volume (eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock Failure of the cardiac pump (eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock Mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling (eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock Systemic vasodilation leads to organ hypoperfusion (eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic, or distributive shock (eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with tingling and numbness of hands and feet. He also complains of fatigue and constant pain in his lower limbs. Careful history taking reveals episodes of confusion. Blood investigations reveal anaemia and monoclonal spike.  A radiograph of his femur is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes polyneuropathy, symptoms of hypercalcemia (fatigue, confusion), anaemia and monoclonal spike with image showing lytic lesions in the bone.  All these features are suggestive of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myelomas: Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:

  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years

Signs and symptoms

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
  • Renal failure
  • Anemia
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Other options:

Option A- Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia- It usually occurs in older adults in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (B cell neoplasm). The tumor cells undergo terminal differentiation to plasma cells which secrete monoclonal IgM that causes hyperviscocity syndrome. In this syndrome, light chains secretion very rarely lead to renal failure and bone destruction is not seen.

Option C- Cryoglobulinemia- It results in precipitation of macroglobulins at lower temperatures leading to Raynaud's phenomenon.

Option D- Senile systemic amyloidosis- It refers to systemic deposition of amyloid in elderly patients. The amyloid in this condition is derived from normal TTR (transthyretin). It usually involves the heart.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. On examination, he has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. A disorder due to deficiency in the enzyme tyrosinase is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism. 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterised by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase further acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. 

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. 

Other options-

Option B- Tyrosinemia type 1 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical findings include cirrhosis, liver failure, rickets, failure to thrive, peripheral neuropathy, and boiled cabbage odour. 

Option C- Tyrosinemia type 2 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability. 

Option D- Homocystinuria is caused due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Clinical findings include lens dislocation, thrombotic vascular disease, intellectual disability, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: A male patient with complaints of jaundice and pruritis shows elevated GGT and ALP.  ERCP revealed beading in both intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. A biopsy was done and showed concentric onion ring fibrosis. The autoantibody most likely to be positive in this condition is:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and biopsy findings of onion ring fibrosis are suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). The autoantibody most likely to be positive in this condition is p-ANCA. 

The auto antibodies in the decreasing order of positivity in PSC are p-ANCA>ANA>AMA.

PSC is the diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of the entire biliary tree (intrahepatic and extrahepatic). It results in chronic cholestasis, cirrhosis, portal hypertension and finally liver failure.

Clinical features include cholestatic jaundice, pruritis, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, and fatigue.

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values can be variable. Majority of patients with PSC are positive for perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (pANCA).

Definitive diagnosis is by cholangiographic imaging showing multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is the imaging of choice, cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is done if MRCP is nondiagnostic.

Currently, there is no known curative treatment. Surgical management involves biliary stenting or endoscopic dilatation of strictures. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option for treatment.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and was prescribed ferrous fumarate tablets for 2 months. Which of the following channels help in the absorption of this iron taken orally into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
The channel that helps in the absorption of the iron into the enterocyte is divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Transport of iron across the brush border of the intestinal cells in the ferrous form is accomplished by DMT-1, also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp 2). 

The mechanism of iron absorption and transport - 

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. This iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1). 

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Argemone mexicana, except that _____.

choices.text: Its oil is used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

questions.solution:
The entire Argemone mexicana plant is poisonous, not only the seeds.

Argemone mexicana grows all over India. The plant has spiny leaves and yellow flowers. The seeds are contained in prickly oblong capsules.

The oil is extracted from argemone seeds and contains the toxic alkaloids sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Poisoning leads to epidemic dropsy, characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca. Some patients may develop diminished vision due to glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Treatment includes a healthy diet and supportive treatment of the heart.

questions.text: Normal quiet breathing is caused by repetitive inspiratory signals from which of the following neurons?
questions.solution:
Normal quiet breathing is caused only by repetitive inspiratory signals from the dorsal respiratory group of neurons.

Ventral groups of neurons fire, when forceful expiration is needed like during heavy exercise.

Pneumotaxic center limits the duration of inspiration.
